Risks & Challenges
 
Bringing a new product to life is always challenging with unforeseen issues that arise along the way. Our biggest challenge is to get our products to our backer as soon as possible. As for the manufacturing part, we have great confidence because the manufacturers we use are big, reliable and we had worked with them before. However, our biggest concern is the delivery time. Since our production and shipping time will be around the holidays period, there may be unexpected setbacks and delay in time. We hope you understand and thanks in advanced for your patience. We are committed to bringing our products to you as soon as possible. Thank you again for your support and understanding.

story:
Neuroscience Research Accelerator Fundraising Campaign

What is it?

The NeuroScienceAccelerator is an online service for brain science researchers which will help them find cures and treatments for Alzheimer’s, Schizophrenia, Parkinson’s and other brain illnesses faster. The NeuroScienceAccelerator is for EEG researchers initially and provides them with five valuable time and money saving  services:

  1. Data cleaning (all EEG data must be cleaned and the NeuroScienceAccelerator provides an automated process for this.)
  2.  Proprietary artifact removal  validation model (so that it can assure only noise was removed and not brain function data)
  3. Brain function model. (Our revolutionary brain function modeling system MOST can produce models of brain function that researches have never had available prior to the launch of the NeuroScienceAccelerator.
  4. Load algorithms into the system. (The NeuroScienceAccelerator will enable researchers to upload their algorithms and data so that other researchers have access to them for experimental replication which is key to finding clues to cures)
  5. Brain Function Library (The NeuroScienceAccelerator acts as a brain function library with an ever growing brain function data set classified by stimulus to enable large data set research).

It’s all about cooperation, sharing and crowd sourcing!


The Neuroscience Research Accelerator is an new way of addressing brain science research challenges through using an Internet data processing portal. Existing research procedures for extracting information from data and then organically having multiple labs do replication studies is a slow process. We need to move faster to address the growing global crisis in brain health. We're using advanced technology and the Internet to help. Article: The Birth of the NeuroScienceAccelerator. 

How the NeuroScienceAccelerator helps find cures and treatments FASTER:


Your Contribution

When you make a contribution we give you data processing time on the Neuroscience Research Accelerator at the rate of one minute per dollar donated. You can assign your new Neuroscience Research Accelerator processing time to the investigation of your choice or use it for your own research project.  The following projects: 

(1) Alzheimer's,

(2) Schizophrenia/Bipolar disorder,

(3) Auditory Processing Disorders

are investigations are awaiting time on the NeuroAccelerator. For more information about contributions, see our video describing how you fund a project of your choice.

After your contribution we will send you a request so you can specify to which investigation you would like to give your processing time.

The average experiment contains between 2000 and 5000 minutes of data that must be processed.

1. Alzheimer’s Disease

Canadian researchers in Montreal at a research institution called the INRS in conjunction with researchers at the University of Victoria are collaborating on a project to combine promising new Alzheimer’s detection methods with data mining methods developed at the University of Victoria. Their goal is to create a sensitive, selective, and reliable detector for identifying early-stage Alzheimer’s disease. These researchers will be using the NeuroscienceAccelerator to remove artefacts from their data and to determine what brain function characteristics best reveal mild cognitive impairment leading to Alzheimer’s. Once they have built their detector, the NeuroscienceAccelerator will be used to make the detector easily available to other Alzheimer’s researchers to do replication studies to ultimately determine the reliability of the detector. Researchers doing replication studies will submit their data, test the detector, and publish their results. New data will be aggregated on the NeuroScienceAccelerator, the detection algorithm will be improved based on new data, and new replication studies can take place to test new versions of the algorithm.

2. Schizophrenia/Bipolar disorder

Established researchers at the University of California, Irvine, USA have collected data in a study to reveal markers for two types of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder from a group of healthy individuals.  These researchers are currently awaiting time on the NeuroScienceAccelerator to remove artefacts from their data, use the new data they have collected to test a marker detection idea they created in prior research, and to enhance their marker detection idea using a procedure of brain source localization to improve the selectivity of their marker detection process in distinguishing between types of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder from healthy individuals.

3. Auditory Processing

Researchers in the UK are looking for ways that EEG methods might be used in a standard procedure to identify auditory processing dysfunction in children early.

In a pilot study assessing auditory processing disorders, they found that children with suspected auditory processing issues had different brain activities relating to auditory processing than age-matched controls. Their sample size for the study was small and they need a larger replication study to increase confidence in their finding.  Researchers who choose to replicate this study will use the data cleaning and peak detection algorithms available on the NeuroScienceAccelerator and can enhance the original methodology using the data mining capabilities of the accelerator.



Did you know:

In 2012, the direct costs of caring for those with Alzheimer’s to American society will total an estimated $200 billion, including $140 billion in costs to Medicare and Medicaid.

Unless something is done, the costs of Alzheimer’s in 2050 are estimated to total $1.1 trillion (in today’s dollars). Costs to Medicare and Medicaid will increase nearly 500 percent.

AND that's only one disease! Globally, brain-related illness generates more healthcare related costs and lost income than any other area of health: an estimated $2.0 trillion annually worldwide and $1.3 trillion annually in the U.S.

We believe there is a role for crowdsourcing brain health research and we're putting our technology on the line, so to speak, to work with global researchers, and funders like yourself who view innovation in healthcare as a route to discovering causes, cures, and treatments. So far a significant amount of neuroscience and healthcare research has been slow to find implementation, and become main-stream processes. We believe it is time to bring promising brain science out of the closet and to use new techniques and technologies to accelerate the processes.

The Neuroscience Research Accelerator is an online portal which will enable brain science researchers using electroencephalographic (EEG) brain function data to access state of the art data cleaning, validation processes and analysis techniques so that they can get the most from the data they collect and do it in as short a time as possible. Not only are we crowd funding this portal, but we're going to crowd source brain science research data from around the globe by providing a useful service to researchers for as *low a cost as possible and for many of them for free.

(*A small fee per use will be required outside of special free service arrangements for us to maintain the infrastructure and support a sustainable business model.)

In this new paradigm for research, we can do research faster and smarter by using these new technologies.

We have a road-map of milestones to build the remaining technology to help us help researchers and eventually our health systems to identify dementias, diseases, and disorders such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Schizophrenia, Bipolar disorder, and Epilepsy early. Early detection will help researchers investigate cures and potentially understand causes.

We can do this with your help.

The Impact

The Neuroscience Research Accelerator (that we've nicknamed the NeuroScienceAcceleratorTM) will help the neuroscience research community in their search for better treatments, better pharmaceutical and non-pharmaceutical therapies for the major brain related illnesses of our day.

It does this through: providing a centralized method for data cleaning and processing, adding data to a central brain function library, containing data-driven models of how our brains transfer and process information which all researchers can share. This assists neuroscience research by bringing crowd data to advanced technology for understanding the brain and combining this with learning algorithms that process large amounts of data.

This new approach to neuroscience research will:

(1) provide online easy-to-use sophisticated brain function analysis tools to neuroscience investigators who would normally have to hire a technology expert,

(2) support replication of major brain illness research by making custom data analysis available in an easy-to-use automated form to new researchers doing replication studies,

(3) aggregate data collected from multiple researchers to generate robust data-driven brain function models and statistics, and identify weak but relevant findings in the data, and

(4) make it possible to build a growing aggregate data library for building brain function models which will be available for use in research.

How Your Money Will Be Used

For the 1st round, these funds will enable us to transform our current Alpha-stage portal into our NeuroAccelerator portal and make it accessible to researchers across the globe. The funds will be used for writing software, purchasing additional hardware, and contacting and promoting the service to the neurosciences community. Your contribution will provide in-kind neuroscience research accelerator processing time to a brain disease or dysfunction researcher.  

The Neuroscience Research Accelerator will have the capacity to host multiple simultaneous users to: (1) clean their research data, (2) model their data and contribute to our brain function database which will be used to better understand brain function, (3) allow researchers to use and experiment with existing marker detection algorithms for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder and new markers for Alzheimer's disease.

If Our First Round is Successful We Will Raise Additional Funds To:

(1) receive data from Alzheimer's disease researchers so that we can apply our enhanced algorithms to identify markers, (2) develop a consumer level data gathering system for massive crowd sourcing of relevant brain data for enhancing the brain function library for global researchers, (3) gain regulatory approval for these algorithms to be used outside the research field and in medical applications, (4) to more actively engage global medical doctors in using this system for healthcare applications.

Background

Dr. Philip Zeman founded Applied Brain and Vision Sciences to give non-technical researchers access to the latest technical tools and methodological innovations to investigate their research problems. The key technology was created while Dr. Zeman was doing his Ph.D. work at the University of Victoria. The key technology, called MOST (Multiple-Origin Spatio-Temporal) modeling, is designed for looking at brain function in a deeper more holistic way, so that we can see brain function as a working system, which can significantly aid in understanding how our brains work and be incorporated into the early detection of major brain disease and dysfunction.

 

The Team

Dr. Philip Michael Zeman, Founder & Chief Executive Officer

Dr. Zeman has ten years of direct experience in the design hardware and software systems for scientific and consumer applications. This includes direct experience in the San Francisco Bay Area building devices for such companies as Sony, Apple, and Assistive Technologies Inc.. His experience spans the composite of client-facing activities and product conceptualization to the manufacturing design and final product specifications.

Dr. Zeman has a proven track record in organizing and working with interdisciplinary teams and successfully bringing diverse science and engineering perspectives together to meet a common goal, both within and outside of the university system. Dr. Zeman has a diverse technical, research, and industry-applied skill-set which provides him with the key skills to drive ABV Sciences forward in its servicing of client customer needs and emerging business opportunities

Dr. Zeman holds an interdisciplinary Ph.D. degree that incorporates both Electrical Engineering (advanced signal processing), Neurobiology, and Cognitive Psychology in the real-time analysis of brain function. He has significant research experience in the investigation of biometric and behavioural measurements as applied to the integration of neuroscience and engineering disciplines

Dr. Zeman’s PhD work created the core MOST analysis process which ABV Sciences is commercializing through focusing on its potential to cost-effectively advanced the quantitative understanding of user perceptions and reasoning processes for application in the interactive entertainment industry, the consumer advertising industry, etc., as well as applications in the medical and drug industries where substantial benefits can be gained via facilitating the low-cost real-time understanding of localized brain function and processing.

Dr. Zeman is an adjunct professor in the Department of Psychology at the University of Victoria, Canada where his research focuses on the investigation of brain function and cognition. Dr. Zeman leads a brain-computer interface (BCI) reading group at the University of Victoria that brings together students of multiple disciplines to help them in their understanding of brain function, construction of brain-computer interfaces, and brain-computer game interaction. Dr Zeman is a co-investigator in brain sciences research conducted at the Aarhus University in Denmark.

Chris Holt, Chief Operations Officer & Project Management

Chris has driven the development of groundbreaking technology applications for the
public and NGO sectors in his drive to improve services for the disadvantaged. As co-founder of LogicLynx Technologies Inc. he brought best-in-class electronic case management and public health IT solutions to government and NGO organizations. His team at LogicLynx developed the first fully configurable software as a service (SAAS) Case Management system for Community Based Human Services Providers.

He has assisted many non-profits, businesses and government organizations over the last 25 years in a variety of consulting capacities. Some have included the Centre for Education Information Standards and Services, BC Ministry of Regional Economic Development, Earth Day Foundation, and the BC Ministry of Environment. Recent consultations have included work with Moving Off Campus.com, LinkedIn.com, Linden Labs and Time-Warner AOL.

As a manager, Chris has had responsibility for up to 30 staff at a time in unionized and non-unionized environments. His projects have included strategic communications, business models, media relations, and both online and enterprise technology sales, development, design and implementation.

Scientific Advisory Board 

We have a Science and Technology Advisory Board comprised of members who: (1) represent client groups, target industries that can help us shape our projects and services to meet customer demands and help us have our technologies accepted by appropriate professional organizations and meet design criteria to have the technologies accepted by their organizations, (2) are concerned with the technical implementation, quality of services, and meeting customer demand, (3) scientific interest in brain function and health. 

Matt Kuntz

Executive Director, Montana chapter of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI). Matt Kuntz was born and raised in Helena, Montana. Matt received his bachelor’s degree from West Point and his law degree from the University of Oregon. Matt served as an infantry officer in the Army and was recognized as Distinguished Member of the Thirty Fifth Regiment for his service. Matt was practicing corporate law in Helena when his step-brother, a Montana National Guardsmen who suffered from post traumatic stress disorder, committed suicide. Spurred on by his step-brother’s death, Matt began advocating for effective screening and treatment of post traumatic stress injuries of our returning service members. Senate Bill 711 was the culmination of these efforts. It required multiple, face-to-face mental health screenings throughout America’s fighting force. Senator Ted Kennedy attached the bill to the Defense Authorization Act of 2010 and was signed into law on October 8, 2009.

In June of 2008, Matt took on the role of the National Alliance on Mental Illness for Montana’s (NAMI Montana’s) Executive Director in order to support, educate, and advocate for all Montanans suffering from serious mental illness and their families. Matt’s advocacy efforts on behalf of Montana’s service members and their families were documented in the book, Faces of Combat: PTSD & TBI by Eric Newhouse. Matt was recognized by President Obama in his inauguration festivities as one of eighteen Ordinary Americans Who Have Made An Extraordinary Difference. Matt was also recognized as an Everyday All-Star by People Magazine and Major League Baseball.

Matt is partner at Boyar & Kuntz, PLLC. Matt is a member of the Board of Directors of the Uganda Rural Fund USA, Inc. and Rocky Mountain Development Council. He just released his latest book: Looking for Answers Through Dirty Glasses: Finding the Divine in a Challenging World.

Dr. Stephen Neville, PhD, PEng (BC)

Founder and Director of the Centre for Advanced Security, Privacy, and Information Systems Research (ASPIRe Centre), Faculty of Engineering, University of Victoria.

Dr. Neville has over 20 years of experience in the application, development, and use of high technology solutions by commercial companies. This includes: direct in-industry experience gained primarily in the San Francisco Bay area, first as a consultant on a $200M USD software redevelopment project focusing on applying expert systems technologies to a financial industry consumer loan processing systems, and then as the Principal Analyst on a U.S. Navy Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command (SPAWAR). This was a Security/Information Warfare Defense funded industry-collaborative advanced cyber-security project. This project focused on the development of a real-time computing cluster-based decision support system to support senior cyber-security analysts, with a target deployment environment being the mid-sized (~5,000 computer) non-secure computing networks of U.S. aircraft carriers. Throughout his career, Dr. Neville’s focus has been on industry and government-applied research and development, where this now also includes active involvement in the Alacrity Foundation of Canada’s supported Entrepreneurial Engineering Masters Program at the University of Victoria.

Dr. Neville’s research expertise spans a composite set of areas including statistical signal processing, statistical paper recognition, artificial intelligence and machine learning, larger-scale software systems-of-systems engineering, cluster and cloud computing, cyber-security, and cyber-privacy. The common underlying theme within Dr. Neville’s research and expertise is in the rigorous analysis of large-scale data sets obtained from operational engineering or business systems to develop quantitative assurances around these systems’: operational performances, their cyber-security, and/or their ability to appropriately protect private and proprietary information, particularly as required under the relevant privacy laws and regulations.

Dr. Neville is the Founder and Director of the Centre for Advanced Security, Privacy, and Information Systems Research (ASPIRe Centre), Faculty of Engineering, University of Victoria, a provincially supported research centre of 19 regular faculty within the Computer Science and Electrical and Computer Engineering Departments, as well as a number university internal and external associated members. Dr. Neville is one of 15 founding academic members of Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC) of Canada’s national cyber-security focused strategic network - the Interconnected Systems Security Network (ISSNet). Dr. Neville’s own Information Security and Privacy Research (InSPiRe) Laboratory focuses on industry-collaborative research projects, having raised over $1.5M in research funding to date. Dr. Neville is the author or co-author on 88 research works split as: 64 refereed publications, 3 patent submissions (one US and one PCT application in the final publication stage), and 21 technical reports (12 of which were industry/government submitted). Dr. Neville is a member of the IEEE, the ACM, and a registered Professional Engineering in the Province of British Columbia.

Dr. Robin T. Wakefield, Ph.D. 

Senior Analyst for West Analytics. Dr. Wakefield specializes in analyzing, assessing and architecting technology solutions for clients with highly secure or sensitive computational environments. This includes governments, law enforcement agencies, researchers, financial institutions and commercial organizations concerned with protecting critical business data and information. He currently has security, privacy and compliance oversight for the British Columbia Government Electronic Health Records project on behalf of Oracle Corporation.

Dr. Ron Skelton

Associate Professor, University of Victoria Department of Psychology.
Areas: Cognitive neuroscience, Spatial navigation, Recovery of function after brain damage.
(http://web.uvic.ca/psyc/people/faculty/skelton.php)

Dr. Donna Buna, Pharm D

Coordinator of Pharmacy Residency Program at Vancouver Island Health Authority.
Areas: Pharmacist for 31 years. Working clinically and collaboratively with other health professionals to help people improve their health and their quality of life. Areas of interest are in geriatrics and pain management.
(http://ca.linkedin.com/pub/donna-buna-pharm-d/3...)

A.W. Robertson, PhD

Psychology Department, Vancouver Island University
University-College Professor, Department of Psychology at Vancouver Island University (formerly Malaspina University-College) for the past 22 years and Adjunct Associate Professor, Department of Psychology and Faculty of Graduate Studies at the University of Victoria (2005 - currently).
Dr. Robertson’s specialties include training in Human and Comparative Neuroscience Research Methods, Clinical Neurophysiological Assessment, Neuropsychological Assessment, Assessment and Remediation of Communication Disorders (Vision & Hearing), Vision Science and a Hospital Practicum in Rehabilitation Psychology (Carleton University, University of Ottawa, Children’s Hospital of Eastern Ontario, Royal Ottawa Regional Rehabilitation Centre)

His teaching experience includes 27 years at Simon Fraser University, Douglas College and Vancouver Island University (formerly Malaspina University-College). Teaching areas include: introductory psychology, biopsychology, research methods, sensation, perception, drugs & behaviour, psychophysiology, physiological psychology, human neuropsychology, neuroscience methods and cognitive neuroscience. Areas of student research supervision include: Human neuropsychology, cognitive neuroscience (behavioural, electrophysiological (EEG) and biomagnetic (MEG) measures), human-computer interfacing with electromyography and brain trauma rehabilitation. His current research includes Event-Related Potential and Behavioural Studies of language, attention and musical processing.

Dr. Robertson’s applied and clinical work includes more than 25 years developing and applying neuropsychological and neurophysiological measures of sensory, perceptual and cognitive processing with persons undergoing technical training or who require rehabilitation subsequent to traumatic brain injury (Former Director of Applied Brain Behaviour Systems Ltd.). Development and application of computer-based cognitive retraining protocols within Rehabilitation Programs for clients with cognitive difficulties associated with traumatic brain injury. This work has involved extensive collaboration with health professionals such as speech and language pathologists, occupational therapists and clinical neuropsychologists.

Dr. Robertson has performed numerous medical-legal neurophysiological assessments of persons suffering cognitive difficulties subsequent to traumatic brain injury (for Applied Brain Behaviour Systems Ltd.) and has testified as an expert witness in the area of Evoked Potential Brain Mapping and Information Processing within the B.C. Supreme Court and the Court of the Queen's Bench in New Brunswick.

His research also includes: Psychophysiological studies of sensory, perceptual and cognitive function in Humans employing Electroencephalographic (EEG) and Bio magnetic (MEG) Recordings and psychophysical research on colour vision. Collaborative research in the Cognitive Neuropsychology of Spatial Cognition and Spatial Behaviour with Dr. Ron Skelton and Dr. Philip Zeman (UVic).

 

Technical Details

For those of you interested in the details of how the Neuroscience Research Accelerator will help to move brain research forward, we have provided some additional information below.

(1) easy to access and easy-to-use sophisticated brain function analysis tools

Many of the new methodologies for processing EEG data that contain hints about how our brains work and malfunction in the presence of disease require a sophisticated technical background to use them correctly and efficiently. We have been implementing these tools in such a way as to make them easy to use by the non-technical neuroscience expert so that: (i) extra technical experts do not have to be hired to support the neuroscientist, and (ii) so that the neuroscience expert can focus on the science rather than writing software and learning analytical methods. The NeuroScienceAccelerator provides these tools so the user does not have to purchase expensive specialized software packages.

(2) leading research data analysis scripts and custom software available for replication of leading research

It is a necessity to replicate findings of an experiment to increase the certainty that an effect found in one experiment is real. This requirement for replication is actually a requirement that slows the research field significantly because replicating prior research isn’t sexy. It is however a necessity in learning about a research field, advancing the field, and is a good way for researchers to add to their publication record. It is to the advantage of leading researchers to make their methods available on the Neuroscience Research Accelerator because it will make it easier for others to follow in their footsteps and cite the peer-reviewed publications in which the methods were first published and any other related publications. For example, we can use this to help in the replication research for brain disease/dysfunction markers such as those related to schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and Alzheimer's disease.

(3) Aggregating data collected in multiple locations makes it possible to extract information from data that we could not otherwise find

This allows us to: (i) build realistic models describing how our brains process information and how our brains begin to fail in the presence of a disease or disorder, and (ii) find rarely occurring markers in the data that could be key in understanding important details about how our brains work and about brain-related disease and dysfunction.

(4) anyone can send us data for processing and contribute to our project

We will receive data from medical, research, and consumer grade EEG systems and incorporate these data into our processes to help us understand brain function. We will provide access to the system so as many people as possible can process data for their own needs and also contribute their data for processing as aggregate data to build sophisticated brain function models to better understand brain function and brain-related disease.


For even more information or more technical details please go to our company website:

www.neuroaccelerator.com


Thank you to all the photographers from Flickr Community Commons who supplied the photos for the video and power points.

Lauren Tucker Photography

(1) provide online easy-to-use sophisticated brain function analysis tools to neuroscience investigators who would normally have to hire a technology expert,
(2) support replication of major brain illness research by making custom data analysis available in an easy-to-use automated form to new researchers doing replication studies,
(3) aggregate data collected from multiple researchers to generate robust data-driven brain function models and statistics, and identify weak but relevant findings in the data, and
(4) make it possible to build a growing aggregate data library for building brain function models which will be available for use in research.
How Your Money Will Be Used
For the 1st round, these funds will enable us to transform our current Alpha-stage portal into our NeuroAccelerator portal and make it accessible to researchers across the globe. The funds will be used for writing software, purchasing additional hardware, and contacting and promoting the service to the neurosciences community. Your contribution will provide in-kind neuroscience research accelerator processing time to a brain disease or dysfunction researcher.  
The Neuroscience Research Accelerator will have the capacity to host multiple simultaneous users to: (1) clean their research data, (2) model their data and contribute to our brain function database which will be used to better understand brain function, (3) allow researchers to use and experiment with existing marker detection algorithms for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder and new markers for Alzheimer's disease.
If Our First Round is Successful We Will Raise Additional Funds To:
(1) receive data from Alzheimer's disease researchers so that we can apply our enhanced algorithms to identify markers, (2) develop a consumer level data gathering system for massive crowd sourcing of relevant brain data for enhancing the brain function library for global researchers, (3) gain regulatory approval for these algorithms to be used outside the research field and in medical applications, (4) to more actively engage global medical doctors in using this system for healthcare applications.
Background
Dr. Philip Zeman founded Applied Brain and Vision Sciences to give non-technical researchers access to the latest technical tools and methodological innovations to investigate their research problems. The key technology was created while Dr. Zeman was doing his Ph.D. work at the University of Victoria. The key technology, called MOST (Multiple-Origin Spatio-Temporal) modeling, is designed for looking at brain function in a deeper more holistic way, so that we can see brain function as a working system, which can significantly aid in understanding how our brains work and be incorporated into the early detection of major brain disease and dysfunction.
 
The Team
Dr. Philip Michael Zeman, Founder & Chief Executive Officer
Dr. Zeman has ten years of direct experience in the design hardware and software systems for scientific and consumer applications. This includes direct experience in the San Francisco Bay Area building devices for such companies as Sony, Apple, and Assistive Technologies Inc.. His experience spans the composite of client-facing activities and product conceptualization to the manufacturing design and final product specifications.
Dr. Zeman has a proven track record in organizing and working with interdisciplinary teams and successfully bringing diverse science and engineering perspectives together to meet a common goal, both within and outside of the university system. Dr. Zeman has a diverse technical, research, and industry-applied skill-set which provides him with the key skills to drive ABV Sciences forward in its servicing of client customer needs and emerging business opportunities
Dr. Zeman holds an interdisciplinary Ph.D. degree that incorporates both Electrical Engineering (advanced signal processing), Neurobiology, and Cognitive Psychology in the real-time analysis of brain function. He has significant research experience in the investigation of biometric and behavioural measurements as applied to the integration of neuroscience and engineering disciplines
Dr. Zeman’s PhD work created the core MOST analysis process which ABV Sciences is commercializing through focusing on its potential to cost-effectively advanced the quantitative understanding of user perceptions and reasoning processes for application in the interactive entertainment industry, the consumer advertising industry, etc., as well as applications in the medical and drug industries where substantial benefits can be gained via facilitating the low-cost real-time understanding of localized brain function and processing.
Dr. Zeman is an adjunct professor in the Department of Psychology at the University of Victoria, Canada where his research focuses on the investigation of brain function and cognition. Dr. Zeman leads a brain-computer interface (BCI) reading group at the University of Victoria that brings together students of multiple disciplines to help them in their understanding of brain function, construction of brain-computer interfaces, and brain-computer game interaction. Dr Zeman is a co-investigator in brain sciences research conducted at the Aarhus University in Denmark.
Chris Holt, Chief Operations Officer & Project Management
Chris has driven the development of groundbreaking technology applications for thepublic and NGO sectors in his drive to improve services for the disadvantaged. As co-founder of LogicLynx Technologies Inc. he brought best-in-class electronic case management and public health IT solutions to government and NGO organizations. His team at LogicLynx developed the first fully configurable software as a service (SAAS) Case Management system for Community Based Human Services Providers.
He has assisted many non-profits, businesses and government organizations over the last 25 years in a variety of consulting capacities. Some have included the Centre for Education Information Standards and Services, BC Ministry of Regional Economic Development, Earth Day Foundation, and the BC Ministry of Environment. Recent consultations have included work with Moving Off Campus.com, LinkedIn.com, Linden Labs and Time-Warner AOL.
As a manager, Chris has had responsibility for up to 30 staff at a time in unionized and non-unionized environments. His projects have included strategic communications, business models, media relations, and both online and enterprise technology sales, development, design and implementation.
Scientific Advisory Board 
We have a Science and Technology Advisory Board comprised of members who: (1) represent client groups, target industries that can help us shape our projects and services to meet customer demands and help us have our technologies accepted by appropriate professional organizations and meet design criteria to have the technologies accepted by their organizations, (2) are concerned with the technical implementation, quality of services, and meeting customer demand, (3) scientific interest in brain function and health. 
Matt Kuntz
Executive Director, Montana chapter of the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI). Matt Kuntz was born and raised in Helena, Montana. Matt received his bachelor’s degree from West Point and his law degree from the University of Oregon. Matt served as an infantry officer in the Army and was recognized as Distinguished Member of the Thirty Fifth Regiment for his service. Matt was practicing corporate law in Helena when his step-brother, a Montana National Guardsmen who suffered from post traumatic stress disorder, committed suicide. Spurred on by his step-brother’s death, Matt began advocating for effective screening and treatment of post traumatic stress injuries of our returning service members. Senate Bill 711 was the culmination of these efforts. It required multiple, face-to-face mental health screenings throughout America’s fighting force. Senator Ted Kennedy attached the bill to the Defense Authorization Act of 2010 and was signed into law on October 8, 2009.
In June of 2008, Matt took on the role of the National Alliance on Mental Illness for Montana’s (NAMI Montana’s) Executive Director in order to support, educate, and advocate for all Montanans suffering from serious mental illness and their families. Matt’s advocacy efforts on behalf of Montana’s service members and their families were documented in the book, Faces of Combat: PTSD & TBI by Eric Newhouse. Matt was recognized by President Obama in his inauguration festivities as one of eighteen Ordinary Americans Who Have Made An Extraordinary Difference. Matt was also recognized as an Everyday All-Star by People Magazine and Major League Baseball.
Matt is partner at Boyar & Kuntz, PLLC. Matt is a member of the Board of Directors of the Uganda Rural Fund USA, Inc. and Rocky Mountain Development Council. He just released his latest book: Looking for Answers Through Dirty Glasses: Finding the Divine in a Challenging World.
Dr. Stephen Neville, PhD, PEng (BC)
Founder and Director of the Centre for Advanced Security, Privacy, and Information Systems Research (ASPIRe Centre), Faculty of Engineering, University of Victoria.
Dr. Neville has over 20 years of experience in the application, development, and use of high technology solutions by commercial companies. This includes: direct in-industry experience gained primarily in the San Francisco Bay area, first as a consultant on a $200M USD software redevelopment project focusing on applying expert systems technologies to a financial industry consumer loan processing systems, and then as the Principal Analyst on a U.S. Navy Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command (SPAWAR). This was a Security/Information Warfare Defense funded industry-collaborative advanced cyber-security project. This project focused on the development of a real-time computing cluster-based decision support system to support senior cyber-security analysts, with a target deployment environment being the mid-sized (~5,000 computer) non-secure computing networks of U.S. aircraft carriers. Throughout his career, Dr. Neville’s focus has been on industry and government-applied research and development, where this now also includes active involvement in the Alacrity Foundation of Canada’s supported Entrepreneurial Engineering Masters Program at the University of Victoria.
Dr. Neville’s research expertise spans a composite set of areas including statistical signal processing, statistical paper recognition, artificial intelligence and machine learning, larger-scale software systems-of-systems engineering, cluster and cloud computing, cyber-security, and cyber-privacy. The common underlying theme within Dr. Neville’s research and expertise is in the rigorous analysis of large-scale data sets obtained from operational engineering or business systems to develop quantitative assurances around these systems’: operational performances, their cyber-security, and/or their ability to appropriately protect private and proprietary information, particularly as required under the relevant privacy laws and regulations.
Dr. Neville is the Founder and Director of the Centre for Advanced Security, Privacy, and Information Systems Research (ASPIRe Centre), Faculty of Engineering, University of Victoria, a provincially supported research centre of 19 regular faculty within the Computer Science and Electrical and Computer Engineering Departments, as well as a number university internal and external associated members. Dr. Neville is one of 15 founding academic members of Natural Sciences and Engineering Research Council (NSERC) of Canada’s national cyber-security focused strategic network - the Interconnected Systems Security Network (ISSNet). Dr. Neville’s own Information Security and Privacy Research (InSPiRe) Laboratory focuses on industry-collaborative research projects, having raised over $1.5M in research funding to date. Dr. Neville is the author or co-author on 88 research works split as: 64 refereed publications, 3 patent submissions (one US and one PCT application in the final publication stage), and 21 technical reports (12 of which were industry/government submitted). Dr. Neville is a member of the IEEE, the ACM, and a registered Professional Engineering in the Province of British Columbia.
Dr. Robin T. Wakefield, Ph.D. 
Senior Analyst for West Analytics. Dr. Wakefield specializes in analyzing, assessing and architecting technology solutions for clients with highly secure or sensitive computational environments. This includes governments, law enforcement agencies, researchers, financial institutions and commercial organizations concerned with protecting critical business data and information. He currently has security, privacy and compliance oversight for the British Columbia Government Electronic Health Records project on behalf of Oracle Corporation.
Dr. Ron Skelton
Associate Professor, University of Victoria Department of Psychology.Areas: Cognitive neuroscience, Spatial navigation, Recovery of function after brain damage.(http://web.uvic.ca/psyc/people/faculty/skelton.php)Dr. Donna Buna, Pharm D
Coordinator of Pharmacy Residency Program at Vancouver Island Health Authority.Areas: Pharmacist for 31 years. Working clinically and collaboratively with other health professionals to help people improve their health and their quality of life. Areas of interest are in geriatrics and pain management.(http://ca.linkedin.com/pub/donna-buna-pharm-d/3...)A.W. Robertson, PhD
Psychology Department, Vancouver Island UniversityUniversity-College Professor, Department of Psychology at Vancouver Island University (formerly Malaspina University-College) for the past 22 years and Adjunct Associate Professor, Department of Psychology and Faculty of Graduate Studies at the University of Victoria (2005 - currently).Dr. Robertson’s specialties include training in Human and Comparative Neuroscience Research Methods, Clinical Neurophysiological Assessment, Neuropsychological Assessment, Assessment and Remediation of Communication Disorders (Vision & Hearing), Vision Science and a Hospital Practicum in Rehabilitation Psychology (Carleton University, University of Ottawa, Children’s Hospital of Eastern Ontario, Royal Ottawa Regional Rehabilitation Centre)
His teaching experience includes 27 years at Simon Fraser University, Douglas College and Vancouver Island University (formerly Malaspina University-College). Teaching areas include: introductory psychology, biopsychology, research methods, sensation, perception, drugs & behaviour, psychophysiology, physiological psychology, human neuropsychology, neuroscience methods and cognitive neuroscience. Areas of student research supervision include: Human neuropsychology, cognitive neuroscience (behavioural, electrophysiological (EEG) and biomagnetic (MEG) measures), human-computer interfacing with electromyography and brain trauma rehabilitation. His current research includes Event-Related Potential and Behavioural Studies of language, attention and musical processing.
Dr. Robertson’s applied and clinical work includes more than 25 years developing and applying neuropsychological and neurophysiological measures of sensory, perceptual and cognitive processing with persons undergoing technical training or who require rehabilitation subsequent to traumatic brain injury (Former Director of Applied Brain Behaviour Systems Ltd.). Development and application of computer-based cognitive retraining protocols within Rehabilitation Programs for clients with cognitive difficulties associated with traumatic brain injury. This work has involved extensive collaboration with health professionals such as speech and language pathologists, occupational therapists and clinical neuropsychologists.
Dr. Robertson has performed numerous medical-legal neurophysiological assessments of persons suffering cognitive difficulties subsequent to traumatic brain injury (for Applied Brain Behaviour Systems Ltd.) and has testified as an expert witness in the area of Evoked Potential Brain Mapping and Information Processing within the B.C. Supreme Court and the Court of the Queen's Bench in New Brunswick.
His research also includes: Psychophysiological studies of sensory, perceptual and cognitive function in Humans employing Electroencephalographic (EEG) and Bio magnetic (MEG) Recordings and psychophysical research on colour vision. Collaborative research in the Cognitive Neuropsychology of Spatial Cognition and Spatial Behaviour with Dr. Ron Skelton and Dr. Philip Zeman (UVic).
 
Technical Details
For those of you interested in the details of how the Neuroscience Research Accelerator will help to move brain research forward, we have provided some additional information below.
(1) easy to access and easy-to-use sophisticated brain function analysis tools
Many of the new methodologies for processing EEG data that contain hints about how our brains work and malfunction in the presence of disease require a sophisticated technical background to use them correctly and efficiently. We have been implementing these tools in such a way as to make them easy to use by the non-technical neuroscience expert so that: (i) extra technical experts do not have to be hired to support the neuroscientist, and (ii) so that the neuroscience expert can focus on the science rather than writing software and learning analytical methods. The NeuroScienceAccelerator provides these tools so the user does not have to purchase expensive specialized software packages.
(2) leading research data analysis scripts and custom software available for replication of leading research
It is a necessity to replicate findings of an experiment to increase the certainty that an effect found in one experiment is real. This requirement for replication is actually a requirement that slows the research field significantly because replicating prior research isn’t sexy. It is however a necessity in learning about a research field, advancing the field, and is a good way for researchers to add to their publication record. It is to the advantage of leading researchers to make their methods available on the Neuroscience Research Accelerator because it will make it easier for others to follow in their footsteps and cite the peer-reviewed publications in which the methods were first published and any other related publications. For example, we can use this to help in the replication research for brain disease/dysfunction markers such as those related to schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and Alzheimer's disease.
(3) Aggregating data collected in multiple locations makes it possible to extract information from data that we could not otherwise find
This allows us to: (i) build realistic models describing how our brains process information and how our brains begin to fail in the presence of a disease or disorder, and (ii) find rarely occurring markers in the data that could be key in understanding important details about how our brains work and about brain-related disease and dysfunction.
(4) anyone can send us data for processing and contribute to our project
We will receive data from medical, research, and consumer grade EEG systems and incorporate these data into our processes to help us understand brain function. We will provide access to the system so as many people as possible can process data for their own needs and also contribute their data for processing as aggregate data to build sophisticated brain function models to better understand brain function and brain-related disease.
 For even more information or more technical details please go to our company website:
www.neuroaccelerator.com

Thank you to all the photographers from Flickr Community Commons who supplied the photos for the video and power points.

story:
What it does

ThoughtEngine raises the bar for task and project management applications by automating the process of transforming a user's thoughts, notes, and emails into a list of action items with defined expected outcomes.  The engine behind the app works by identifying keywords and tags associated with thoughts  or emails entered by the user, using the keywords to contruct the generalized issue the thought revolves around, then based on key variables makes a high level recommendation to the user for how they should follow up with the thought, what the outcome should be, and when the user should get it done.

 

 

Who this can help, and how

The ThoughtEngine app helps business teams make decisions that place them closer to their desired outcomes, faster. We are targeting small businesses, business units, and freelancers (artists, marketing, real estate, consultants, and other project-based businesses/industries).  

Teams and businesses that are looking to expand face two issues in managing work activity that if unsolved will ultimately limit growth:

  1. Decision speed - As the amount of information and the number of decisions increase, teams get caught in a cycle of indecision and planning, not acting
  2. Reaching desired outcomes: Teams get caught up in the process and fail to maintain enough momentum to complete projects on time

The app increases the productivity, hence the growth potential, of a small team or business by using machine learning algorithms to process information shared between users within the context of a project and predict optimal follow-up actions. The algorithms incorporate past decisions made, as well as tags, keywords and key phrases in communications within the app.

Why we are looking for funding

We are currently beta-testing the core functionality of the app - import of emails, team communications, and the ability to organize thoughts.  We also have the core algorithm behind Intelligent Thought Routing built.  We are looking for funding to help develop our algorithm into code and integrate it with the application - basically to pay developers who are good at building machine learning algorithms.  This has the potential to be a transformative tool for businesses, freelancers, and small teams, and we want to ensure that the design remains responsive to the needs of our end-users.

 

Background

Hi, I'm Shingai Samudzi, co-Founder of the company behind ThoughtEngine.  My background is in software development, product development, and decision science.  I have spent the past year developing a methodology to help improve business decision-making in order to help fuel small business growth - Intelligent Thought Routing - and now am baking it into a mobile application that I call ThoughtEngine.

story:
Peekameet is a crowd-scanning, GPS-based social check-in app for the
business-traveler set that tags and timestamps your location — along with some profile information — which others can use to search, seek and connect with you through.
 
Imagine you're in any number of places you might have visited during your
business trip: the tradeshow floor, the airport terminal, the coffee shop — how many other people are in those same places as you, at the same time, in an unfamiliar city, just yearning for interesting conversation with someone new. Imagine if you could "peek" at their profile and background and pick someone you'd like to meet, mingle and network with, just like that?

That's Peekameet.
 
Peekameet's success relies on the development of a mobile app which will utilize location-based technology, career profiles, LinkedIn and Facebook Connect to leverage shared connections, similar interests, and common demographics.
 
That's why I need you! I need to raise $70,000 to turn my dream of Peekameet into a reality.
 
And I know it will be successful. I'm a "road warrior" myself.
 
Since 1998 I've worked in the heart of cutting edge technology as a Network
Consulting Engineer. I know how isolating it can be working from "the road," and how refreshing it can be when you find someone you truly connect with or have something in common with while you're hundreds or thousands of miles from home. It was during my travels I realized the need for PEEKaMEET, an app to aid people in conquering their networking challenges. PEEKaMEET helps take the "working" of networking.
 
If you want to change the way people meet, support PEEKaMEET

By contributing  to the PEEKaMEET campaign, you will help pioneer a revolutionary mobile product for the business traveling set. In this day and age, every connection counts and every conversation has the potential to lead to something life-changing. Let's change the face of business traveling together!

PEEKaMEET helps professionals and business travelers meet people near where they are or where they plan to go. PEEKaMEET gives checked in and online users the ability to initiate a private chat. It's an ice breaker to creating human connections.

Join PEEKaMEET.com too and attend places and events, or add your own places and events. It's FREE!

Please share this campaign on your social networks and email contact lists.

Thanks for your support and I hope to meet you on PEEKaMEET!

 

PEEKaMEET-Changing the way people meet

story:
Project Summary

Funding for an Note 4 Exynos model for kernel and general device development.

I personally am not invested enough to outright buy it as my own device as I think it's a tad too big for everyday usage and plan on upgrading from my S4 next spring.

However, if there is enough community interest in the matter and desire, I will review this device and as far possible try to re-create all features found in previous Perseus kernel implementations and support the device for the foreseeable future.

The target development device is a SM-N910C or a SM-N910U depending on availability and pricing at the end of the campaign.

If funding is not achieved in the targeted period, all contributors will be refunded their money.

Update

I have aquired a SM-N910C. I will be starting development after publishing a review of the device within the next week. I'll update progress here and on GitHub when things will be ready for publishing.

story:
NOW THAT WE HAVE PASSED THE $20,000 MARK, ALL FUNDS RAISED WILL GO TO THE CANADIAN RED CROSS

 

Help Ottawa's historic Mayfair Theatre buy a Digital Cinema Package (DCP) projector — and stay open for another 80 years!

Celebrating its 80th anniversary this year, the Mayfair Theatre is one of the oldest independent movie houses in all of Canada. In its eight decades of operation, the Mayfair has never been owned by, or affiliated with, any of the major cinema chains.

We're proud of our indie heritage, and that's why we're turning to Indiegogo now.

By the end of 2012, studios and distributors will no longer be making or shipping film prints — period. To stay in business, the Mayfair needs to buy a Digital Cinema Package (DCP) projector.

It’s a big investment, but we’re committed to making it happen. We’re saving and re-investing every nickel we can, but we could really use your help, too.

Please join us, and help keep the Mayfair open for another 80 years!

 

What we're asking

We've been saving and fundraising in the real world for close to a year now, and we've already raised quite a bit toward the purchase of the DCP projector. What we're looking for now is to fill the gap between what we have and what the projector actually costs. 

Specifically, we need to raise another $15,000.00.

Every penny will go toward the purchase, shipping, setup and installation of the projector.

 

What if we beat our goal?

We upgrade the projector.

Anything extra we raise up to $20,000.00 will be put toward the purchase of a scaler, which will allow us to use the DCP projector to show films from DVD, BluRay, Laserdisc, VHS or other formats. 

And we help the Red Cross.

Anything we raise over and above $20,000.00, we will donate to the Red Cross Canada. 

 

What we're offering

What do you get if you donate? In addition to becoming a hero of independent cinema, you can choose from some truly unique and exciting perks, including: 

  • Being thanked by name in our guide!
  • A card that allows you to upsize any candy bar purchase (and gives you free admission on your birthday)!
  • Your name on a plaque on a seat in the Mayfair!
  • A chance to present a movie of your choice at the Mayfair!
  • The privelege to reserve a couch or love seat in our balcony for a year!
  • Free admission to any and all screenings for a year!

 

Why it matters

The shift to digital projection is forcing independent cinemas all across Canada and the US to close, and with them is going a vital artistic, cultural and social experience that's simply not available at the cineplex or on home video.

We helped save the Mayfair when we took over operation of the business in 2008, and we're determined to save it again.

By helping us, you'll be helping preserve:

  • One of the few screens in Ottawa that offers the audience real choice, with programming that includes first-run art, foreign, independent and Canadian cinema,  current and classic Hollywood offerings, cult and exploitation movies, monthly film festivals and special presentations. 
  • A unique and valuable venue for emerging and established independent filmmakers from across Canada and around the world, who visit and screen their work as part of our ongoing Fimmaker In Attendance series.
  • An important community space for local arts, cultural, charitable and non-profit organizations.
  • An architectural landmark that was declared an official heritage building by the City of Ottawa in 2008. 

You don't have to donate to help!

Even if you can’t donate, you can help by spreading the word on Facebook, Twitter and other social media — or in real life! Let your friends know that you support the Mayfair — and they should, too! Here are a couple of sample tweets/posts to get you started. Just copy and paste them!

Help keep @mayfairtheatre open for another 80 years! Donate now at http://www.indiegogo.com/mayfairdigital

I donated to help @mayfairtheatre open for another 80 years! Join me! http://www.indiegogo.com/mayfairdigital

What if we beat our goal?
We upgrade the projector. 
Anything extra we raise up to $20,000.00 will be put toward the purchase of a scaler, which will allow us to use the DCP projector to show films from DVD, BluRay, Laserdisc, VHS or other formats. 
And we help the Red Cross.
Anything we raise over and above $20,000.00, we will donate to the Red Cross Canada. 

 
What we're offering
What do you get if you donate? In addition to becoming a hero of independent cinema, you can choose from some truly unique and exciting perks, including: 

Being thanked by name in our guide!
A card that allows you to upsize any candy bar purchase (and gives you free admission on your birthday)!
Your name on a plaque on a seat in the Mayfair!
A chance to present a movie of your choice at the Mayfair!
The privelege to reserve a couch or love seat in our balcony for a year!
Free admission to any and all screenings for a year!

 


Why it matters
The shift to digital projection is forcing independent cinemas all across Canada and the US to close, and with them is going a vital artistic, cultural and social experience that's simply not available at the cineplex or on home video.
We helped save the Mayfair when we took over operation of the business in 2008, and we're determined to save it again.
By helping us, you'll be helping preserve:

One of the few screens in Ottawa that offers the audience real choice, with programming that includes first-run art, foreign, independent and Canadian cinema,  current and classic Hollywood offerings, cult and exploitation movies, monthly film festivals and special presentations. 
A unique and valuable venue for emerging and established independent filmmakers from across Canada and around the world, who visit and screen their work as part of our ongoing Fimmaker In Attendance series.
An important community space for local arts, cultural, charitable and non-profit organizations.
An architectural landmark that was declared an official heritage building by the City of Ottawa in 2008. 




You don't have to donate to help!
Even if you can’t donate, you can help by spreading the word on Facebook, Twitter and other social media — or in real life! Let your friends know that you support the Mayfair — and they should, too! Here are a couple of sample tweets/posts to get you started. Just copy and paste them!
Help keep @mayfairtheatre open for another 80 years! Donate now at http://www.indiegogo.com/mayfairdigital
I donated to help @mayfairtheatre open for another 80 years! Join me! http://www.indiegogo.com/mayfairdigital

story:
The University of Utah (commissioned by NEC): Larger Monitors and Dual Screens Help Users Edit Text and Spreadsheets

 

Using a larger monitor or dual monitors helped users complete tasks as much as 52 percent faster, saving up to 2.5 hours a day. 

 

 

Many office workers receive the benefit of a 2nd screen while at the office, but this is not always easily available while working from home. 

All the wires and cables needed to connect to power and the computer are unsightly and make moving around to a different room very difficult. And there are never enough sockets to fit all the extras.

A conventional screen is heavy and bulky to carry.  It is a challenge to find plug points, and to connect the screen to the laptop or PC, and to carry around the bundle of wires, plugs etc.

Wouldn’t it be great if you could have a portable totally wirefree second screen to use with your laptop, Mac, iPhone, or Android?  What if you did not need to plug it in or use any cables?

But technology is there to make our lives easier. Introducing OpenScreen!

OpenScreen wirefree touchscreen brings you an advanced touchable multi-touch screen without the cables.

And its easy to use.

Once you switch on the OpenScreen, simplify turn on your phone or laptop.  The OpenScreen device will appear as a device for you to connect to.  Its that easy.

 

 

 

 

 

 

In 2013 Manoj Chwala, innovator and serial entrepreneur, was doing a lot of business travel and one of his biggest bugbears was how to use a second screen when out of the office.  He needed 2 screens to work efficiently but this was quite difficult as there were lots of interface cables and everything seemed to need a power supply.

When working at client offices, remote sites or hotel desks, space & plugs were limited and setup time just took too long.

At this time Windows 8 had been launched and the Netgear Widi “wireless dongle” became available. So Manoj began experimenting with his Sony Vaio Duo to develop a portable wireless connection to a monitor using the Widi(Miracast).

He eventually succeeded in developing a prototype portable wirefree Monitor. 

When he showed the product to his friends they all asked if they could buy one and even the patent lawyers ordered some.  

In 2016 he approached Flextronic and then in 2018 he went to China and started discussions with Chinese manufacturers.

 

Manoj has a track record in innovation, he has worked for a range of blue chip companies before working on startups.  

 

 

 

 

Pat King has spent over 40 years working in various IT roles, mainly in audio and visual sectors.

As the founder of a number of companies, like Voice and Data Systems Ltd, Voipline and  presently CEO of IP King Ltd , Pat has worked with mainly financial entities who have audio recording and video needs in Ireland and UK,

story:
ABOUT PROJECT

The ERPNext community is looking for a Quickbooks connector and wanted to sponsor the development costs.

Coming forward, Indictrans Team has shown interest in building Quickbooks connector for ERPNext.

Feature set of QB-ERPNext Connector is given below:

  • Sales / Purchase Invoice will be created in ERPNext and synced with Quickbooks
  • Customers, Suppliers, Item, Tax, Employee and User will be managed through ERPNext and whenever added new or updated existing one, it will update in Quickbooks
  • Journal Entry against SI/PI will be primarily created in Quickbooks and same will synced to ERPNext or vice versa
  • Migrate opening data from Quickbooks to ERPNext
  • Listing on Quickbooks app store and ERPNext app store
  • Test Cases
  • Documentation

You can find the features list on Github

Complete source code will be maintained in Github repository. The development is already underway, you can have a look at the Github Repository

Tentative delivery date of project is 31st May 2016. Delivery date can extend depending on the issues which might come across from various community users.

Your contribution will go towards the development of this connector and we can expect the connector to be functionally usable by the end of June.

ABOUT INDICTRANS
Indictrans is a specialist ERPNext Consulting Company, with a proven experience in helping organizations significantly reduce costs and improve effectiveness and efficiency through internal process improvements using ERPNext.

Refer Github repository of Indictrans for various works done by Indictrans Team on ERPNext including development, customization and integration for various clients across globe.

Indictrans has helped many customers and partners in building solutions and/or products using ERPNext. Indictrans customer base is in Singapore, Australia, South Africa, Dubai, US, UAE, Saudi Arabia, Thailand, Kuwait etc.

List of various solutions developed using ERPNext for clients are mentioned below:
    •   Church Management System
    •   Distribution Management System
    •   Saloon Management System
    •   Integration of Magento with ERPNext
    •   Integration with Mobile App, Biometric and Barcode
    •   Integration of ERPNext with Zoho Reporting
    •   Integration of ERPNext with vTiger CRM
    •   Market Place for Health Domain
    •   Facility Management Solution
    •   Marketplace for Tailoring Offerings
    •   Marketplace for Public Health Record
    •   Personal Health Record System
    •   ERP Implementation for Manufacturing, Retail and Service Industry
    •   Loyalty Platform Engine
    •   Development and Integration of BI, Dashboards, Reports etc
    •   Integration with Google Business App, Google Calendar, Google Email, Google Contact, Tally and many other legacy software
    •   And many other customization in ERPNext modules

story:
Swiss Cloud

I am sitting here in Zug in the heart of Switzerland
and am typing this document on my Lenovo ThinkPad. I am using Microsoft Word
2013 which is available to me owing to a Citrix receiver on the notebook. In so
doing, Word does not run directly on this device, but rather in a computer
centre deep in the Swiss mountains. The operating system being used which Word
provides as system resources is Microsoft Windows 8. However, Windows 8 does
not run on this device, but rather is run on a virtual machine on the server
farm in the computer centre. Before the beginning of the execution, Word was
streamed into this virtual machine and then started. The file which I create
and then back up will be located in my personal directory in the cloud. Thus, I
can edit it from anywhere in the world and from any device that is available to
me.

We have arrived at a world in which I can use the
device of my choice to work, play, write an e-mail, surf the Internet and
retrieve information. I can work wherever I would like to–whether I am sitting
in the office working on my Samsung notebook, whether I am reading a document
on my Microsoft Surface while eating at home or retrieving my e-mails with my
ThinkPad on the side of a mountain and, if I would like, also answering those
e-mails. I have the choice, I can decide.

This world is fascinating, inspiring, motivating and,
in the years to come, will provide us with freedoms in our work world which
were totally unthinkable in the past. But this world is also new, nebulous,
multi-layered and requires explanations and, for this reason, there are also
specialists…Our Swiss Cloud.

We are the specialists. We show our clients which path
to take. We reveal the options which our clients have available to them with
regards to desktop virtualisation, application virtualisation and server virtualisation.

We ourselves use the technology every day in our
lives, we value it, it brings us freedoms and alters our balance between
freedom and work to create an atmosphere which is very convenient for us and
enables us to attain a harmonious family-career balance.

What You will Give Us & What You will Receive

We will virtualise your entire data centre–on our Swiss cloud platform.

We will utilise the money in order to purchase the required hardware. The existing platform will run on older hardware which will be sufficient only for the expansion of the platform, but not for production.

If we attain the target amount for the investments, we will pass on 10 % of the total amount as a donation.

The Consequences

We want to offer clouds–certainly! We stand out from other service providers because we offer no hosting and no shared environments, but rather genuine cloud services and dedicated environments. The platform is intended for business purposes and is supposed to supplant the local physical data centre through a virtual, secure and dynamic data centre.

Risks & Challenges

There are risks in developing the platform. Although the platform is already up and running during the proof of concept, but there is still a lot of work to do and the fine-tuning is complex. However, we do not want to give up and, as soon as the hardware is available, we will continue on with our best efforts. In addition, we have contacts to many specialists who help us with various thematic areas and conduct a review upon a regular basis.

Other Ways that One can Help

We need hardware, but above all we need clients. If you cannot help with the capital, present our Swiss Cloud to the world.

story:
We really are justlikeyou!

Just take a peek below!

We’re twenty-one students and professionals across five countries with varied and intersecting identities. Simply, we’re going to change lives by providing a safe, clean and anonymous social network for people ages 13+ going through the coming out process. As a startup guided and facilitated by the Dingman Center for Entrepreneurship at the University of Maryland-College Park, the justlikeyou.org network has come a long way from its humble beginnings.

Currently working toward 501c3 (not-for-profit) status, our long-term goals are to: develop technology, coordinate LGBTQA (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, questioning and ally) competency trainings, and connect users from the network to their local communities for needed support through coming out. The funds we raise will help to accomplish these goals and further support our mission.

Bottom line: We are working to eliminate the burden of coming out.

    How will we accomplish the goal?

    Well, that’s as easy as 1-2-3 (for the user!)

    The behind-the-scenes magic, however, is a bit more complicated.


    This is how it works:

    • Via a Likert Scale questionnaire that will be filled out during the sign-up process, like the one below, the justlikeyou.org staff—backed by a team of clinical psychologists and LGBTQ professionals—has developed a tool to quantify over-arching emotions commonly felt during a user’s coming-out process.

    • Then, leveraging a justlikeyou.org’s algorithm, we’ll match the new user to other users and JLY (justlikeyou.org) volunteers who have documented similar responses.

    • Finally, the users will be able to share and communicate their experiences in a safe and supportive environment through secure messaging.

    This idea is actually very simple at its core: users who have felt similar emotions during their coming out process can share their own personal stories in order to encourage comfortable and helpful dialogue. While this will be accomplished initially through individual inbox messages, we look forward to introducing additional secure chatting features once we grow our membership.

    As you might imagine, the matching process is not an exact science. If any users aren’t looking to speak to someone who is feeling the same way they are, that user will also have the option to interact with JLY volunteers who have been through coming out or search for users based on their own criteria.

    Great, is this actually safe?

    Before the core justlikeyou.org team decided to move forward with this venture, safety and anonymity for all users was the top priority.  As such, we’ve incorporated several features that maximize safety. We’ll restrict the exchange of personal information such as:

    • Pictures

    • Videos

    • Street address

    • Derogatory/defamatory language

    Remember, this is a resource that connects real people with real experiences. We are looking to have the personal narrative guide the conversation around coming out, not someone’s physical appearance.

    Though we DO NOT provide any in-crisis, medical, and/or mental health advise we would like to be able to provide users with resources for other organizations that operate for those purposes.

    So, why are we doing this?

    Every staff member who is working with the justlikeyou.org network has experienced in one way or another the complexity of emotions associated with the coming out process – even when surrounded by trusted supporters. We identify with the struggles and anxieties associated with coming out. We want to help rid the burden of coming out by providing a safe space for LGBTQ and allied individuals to talk about their experiences with one another.

    This is why we’ve employed a global approach to our business model. Coming out is not uniquely American; it's a global issue and geographically unique. As a flattened world, we can glean many insights from people throughout the world. Thus, we’ve designed the network to be centered on that will connect users and volunteers with a unique focus outside the 50 states. 

    Why we need YOU!

    We are hoping you will contribute to the cause. By financially backing the creation of this online community, you are directly helping to eliminate the burden of coming out.

    You’re funding a community, a safe space for people looking to become more comfortable with their identity. You’re increasing an individual’s confidence and you will be a driving force behind the LGBTQA movement.


    Please help us out!

    We need to raise $50,000. Sounds like a lot because it is.

    This money will be used immediately to enhance our volunteer training curriculum, training new JLY volunteers, increase site functionality, and develop a mobile app extension to take JLY worldwide.

    We realize not reaching our goal is a possibility, but funding will still go proportionately toward mobile technology development, enhanced site functionality, composing an education curriculum for volunteer trainings, and the costs of volunteer training. Obviously, if we weren't able to reach our goal, funds will be allocated at lower amounts.

    Are there perks for donating?

    Of course! We have perks that we've divided into two categories: Store Incentives and Experience Incentives. Below, you’ll see a list of these perks; to the right, you can see a more in-depth description of these perks.Store Incentives:

    • ($5) JLY Supporter Status

    • ($15) JLY Lanyard

    • ($25) JLY Reusable Water Bottle

    • ($40) Heron Head Clothiers Special Edition JLY Bow Tie

    • ($50) JLY #LoveIsLove T-shirt

    Experience Incentives:

    • Train a volunteer

    • Founding Funder status

    • Access to justlikeyou.org a month before launch

    • 2 tickets to the launch party and a meet & greet with the founding team

    • Private dinner with founding directors of justlikeyou.org

    • JLY Sponsor Status

      • Bronze

      • Silver

        Gold

      • Platinum


    More ways to GET INVOLVED!

    We realize not everyone can donate money. See below for other impactful ways to contribute:


      1. Share the news about our campaign with your friends! You never know who may be looking for an outlet.

      2. Like and Follow us on Social:

        1. Facebook | www.facebook.com/justlikeyou.org

        2. Twitter  | www.twitter.com/justlikeyouorg 

          Use hashtags #jlyWorldwide #LetsGoGo

        3. Instagram | www.instagram.com/justlikeyouorg 

          Use hashtags #jlyWorldwide #LetsGoGo

        4. Youtube | www.youtube.com/user/justlikeyouorg

      3. Sign up to become an online volunteer at justlikeyou.org by emailing Robby.Warren@justlikeyou.org

      4. Join the movement! Have your business partner with us or join the team - contact our founder, Brooks Gabel at Brooks.Gabel@justlikeyou.org, to get involved today.

      5. Spread the word!


    Thank You!

    We hope that you’ll take this journey with us and help end the emotional burden of going through the coming out process. In the end, we’re all #justlikeyou. Thanks :)

    ______________________________________________________________________________

      Press Inquiries:

      CONTACT: Alex Gabriel | Business Strategy Lead | alex.gabriel@justlikeyou.org

      The Huffington Post: http://huff.to/1gfwixa

      Chispired: http://bit.ly/1oXMXf4 

      Diamondback: http://bit.ly/1bM14ei

      Westfield Voice: http://bit.ly/1jWjNfj

      Dingman Center for Entreprenuership (1): http://bit.ly/1iUc1T3

      Dingman Center for Entreprenuership (2): http://bit.ly/1mqDFXw

Thank You!We hope that you’ll take this journey with us and help end the emotional burden of going through the coming out process. In the end, we’re all #justlikeyou. Thanks :)______________________________________________________________________________
