story:
The Legacy engine is a revolutionary new type of internal combustion engine. 

Legacy Gen002.5B Prototype Assembled
Legacy Gen 002.5B Prototype at the University of Tennessee’s Advanced Powertrains, Controls & System Integration (APCSI) automotive research lab

What makes the Legacy engine Revolutionary?

The Legacy engine offers tremendous benefits over any existing or development stage engines, and has the potential for significant global impact from:

 

• Better fuel economy
- 20% More efficient than ANY conventional engine
- Innovative Combustion Geometry
- Saving the average family $800 per year in fuel expense

• Less Pollution
- 20% less fuel is needed to make the same power
- Reduce the amount of carbon emitted by 8 tons per vehicle per year for a  long haul tractor trailer.
- Alternative Fuels: Can operate on any fuel including biodiesel, natural gas and hydrogen

• Small, lightweight, and powerful
- 1/4th the size and weight of a conventional engine
- Nine combustion cycles per rotation of the drive shaft
- A single rotor Legacy is equivalent to an 18 cylinder four-stroke engine

• Lower Cost
- Cost 50% less to manufacture
- Only 12 major components
- No eccentric or reciprocating motion; less vibration & wear
- Simple and adaptable design

These predicted benefits are based on testing, simulation and analysis of the Legacy engine.

Why is this important to you?

If you're willing to help us then one day in the not too distant future you might have a Legacy engine in your car. This will effect you in several ways. First your car will cost you a lot less because the Legacy engine cost less than 50% of a current engine. Second, it will save you at least 20% every time you go to the pump, which is about $800.00 a year for a typical family. Third, you will be able to buy a hybrid car that has plenty of power when you need it and plenty of truck room because the Legacy engine is so small and lightweight that the batteries will fit under the hood where they belong! Last but not least, you will produce a great deal less pollution when you drive a car with a Legacy engine powering it.

Why is this important to everyone?

The commercial Legacy engine would provide the marketplace with a more efficient engine.  The benefits of Legacy’s efficiency would a drastic reduction in Greenhouse Gas emissions, as well as lowering the demand for oil.  In a broader sense, it could reduce the United States’ dependency on foreign oil, provide a technological advantage in a critical market, and lead to the creation of “green” jobs.  The core technology and its deployment uses existing infrastructure which will reduce the cost and time of implementation into the marketplace.

Our Team:

We are a group of highly dedicated individuals committed to making the Legacy engine technology available to everyone. Our team consists of experts in engine design and development as well highly qualified people in business development and financial management.  This team is the backbone of the company and has made our development to date possible. For over five years our team has invested their time, energy and money into the Legacy technology. With your help we can take the next critical step! Scroll down for detailed Bios.

Why We Need Your Help:

We need your help to build the GEN002.5X prototype! This is the next and most critical step in getting the Legacy engine to market. Over the past few years we have successfully addressed many of the technical challenges related to the Legacy engine. Now we need to bring it all together. The GEN002.5X will leverage everything we have learned and will result in a prototype that can be tested for long periods of time. To do this we need to design and fabricate a new housing that can keep the engine cool during these tests. We can do this in less than a year but we need you help to make it happen!

Fluid flow and heat transfer analysis of Gen002.5X housing

The following shows the design and fabrication of the Gen2.5B housing. This is similar to our project but much more simple. The Gen2.5X housing design will incorporate information from our fluid flow and heat transfer analysis (shown above) to insure it can dissipate the heat created during combustion testing.

Design Drawings for the Gen002.5B Housing
Fabrication of Gen002.5B Housing

Stretch Goals:

If we are able to raise $250,000 then we will be able to take the next step in the development process by making Legacy Gen002.5X a "stand alone" prototype. We will achieve this by integrating the subsystems such as a radiator, turbo/super charger, etc... By making the Legacy Gen002.5X “stand-alone” prototype we will have taken the next major step in our development.

Of course it we are SUPER successful in our effort then we will be able to achieve more than this so please help us as much as you can!

What You Get!

We have all kinds of unique and historical rewards for you and many of them are exclusives to this effort. The best thing we have to offer is a front row seat to this exciting project. All of our backers will have access to information as we move forward but some of you will get to see the technical data and even see tests streamed in real time. To learn more about this please read the letter from our CEO below.

Whether you give a little or a lot we want to thank you in advance for helping us. We believe the Legacy engine will have a significant and positive impact for everyone. Those that help make it happen deserve not only our gratitude but also something to commemorate their efforts toward making this project happen. The rewards are listed on the bar to the left but we also have detailed descriptions and pictures below. So just scroll down to see them. There is a lot of technical info below so just keep going and you will find them!

A Letter From Our CEO

 

 

The Legacy engine technology:

How Does it Work?

 This animation shows the basic operation of the Legacy engine as well as it major components and how they function.

 

The Legacy engine is low speed high torque planetary engine, comprised of a central rotor and orbiting elements, named rotons. The figure below depicts the Legacy engine configuration, with major components labeled. It also illustrates the combustion processes occurring symmetrically on the three faces of each of the three rotons. These processes enable the Legacy engine to execute nine complete thermodynamic cycles in a single revolution.

 

Innovative Combustion Geometry: The geometry of the Legacy engine increases the volume of the combustion chamber with shaft rotation differently than conventional piston/crankshaft engines. This yields increased efficiency from the air standard model (described below), by generating higher pressures during the expansion process.

Beyond the gains in efficiency predicted by the air-standard models, the engine geometry also provides a unique combustion chamber and unique combustion process. As the roton reaches the minimum volume position, the working combustion volume is divided into: 1) the leading volume; and 2) the trailing volume, as shown in the adjacent figure.

Fuel is injected into the leading volume after volume division, continuing as the roton moves across the housing peak. The trailing volume contains only compressed air, forced into the leading volume as the roton continues past the housing peak. The compressed air is highly turbulent, being forced through the narrow clearance between the roton and the housing.

This Legacy engine combustion process is enhanced in two ways: 1) the fuel/air mixture in the leading volume is closer to the stoichiometric requirement, enhancing ignition, while the overall operating mixture remains lean (typical of compression ignition); and 2) the highly turbulent air, forced from the trailing volume, promotes mixing, resulting in more efficient combustion.

Inherent Rotary Motion: The Legacy engine forces combustion pressure to be applied directly to the output shaft as torque, eliminating the reciprocating-to-rotary mechanism in conventional piston/crankshaft engines. This increases efficiency by avoiding friction loss from thrust loading of the pistons. It also yields improved vibration characteristics and reduces the engine part count.

Aspiration Simplicity: Aspiration of the Legacy engine is accomplished with ports rather than valves. This eliminates a complex subsystem, lowering cost and improving reliability.

Engine Component Simplicity: Many Legacy engine components have simple design geometry, surfaces of revolution or extruded profiles. These simple shapes allow the application of advanced ceramic and composite materials, which are less easily used in the complex geometry of conventional engines. The Legacy engine can be configured as “shaft-horizontal” or “shaft-vertical”, increasing design latitude of downstream power transmission components, and packaging options.

Thermodynamic Analysis
The University of Tennessee has performed a thermodynamic analysis using an air-standard cycle with Wiebe function heat addition. This analysis of the Legacy engine was also compared to a crankshaft engine with the same displacement and compression ratio and operating with the same emissions-compliant fuel calibration.


The figure above shows modeling results for this comparison. We predict an increase in efficiency of approximately sixteen percent (16%).
Conclusion
Thermodynamic analysis of the Legacy engine predicts –
• An increase in thermal efficiency of approximately 16% over an equivalent crankshaft engine
• Enhanced mixing of the fuel and air due to the unique combustion chamber and unique combustion process should increase the overall efficiency gain to greater than 20%
• Additional increases in efficiencies can be achieved through continued development and by employing state-of-the-art subsystems currently available.


Development Efforts To Date

PST has maintained a scientific approach throughout the research and development efforts pertaining to the Legacy engine. To date we have designed, fabricated and tested four iterations of the Legacy engine and have successfully addressed many of the primary technical challenges we face in commercializing the technology. Additional technical challenges exist, but are typical of challenges that must be addressed in any internal combustion engine development programs, and are considered to represent a low level of risk. The following outlines the progress to date. Testing and evaluation of the Legacy engine are conducted at the University of Tennessee’s Advanced Powertrains, Controls & System Integration (APCSI) automotive research laboratory.


GEN001 Proof of Geometry

The GEN001 was tested at a rotational speed of 250 rpm, less than typical cranking speed, to avoid damaging the prototype. The data confirmed that seals can function across pressure boundary dividing combustion chamber.

GEN002 Proof of Concept

The GEN002 validated the viability of the Legacy engine and provided a clear path forward. Lessons learned guided further development.

Click image to see the Gen002 being tested



GEN002.5 Advanced Concept Demonstrator

In the fourth quarter of 2010, PST entered into a contract with the National Transportation Research Center, Inc. (NTRCI) to investigate an asymmetric tip seal system and a flush mount fuel injector nozzle for use in the Legacy engine. This effort, funded by the Department of Energy, has validated the functionality of the asymmetric tip seal system as well as the flush mount fuel injector nozzles. The asymmetric tip seal provides a simple solution that will make the Legacy engine easier to manufacture and lower the cost of production. Continued R&D is required to optimize the design but the test results indicate the design is sound and provides the solution to this technical challenge.

Data Aquisition
Fuel pump and Injectors


The roton tip seal represented the key technical challenge to the commercialization of the Legacy engine however; a solution to this challenge has been developed and successfully tested. 


The asymmetric tip seal system was integrated into the GEN002, now designated the GEN002.5A & B.

The Gen002.5 was tested at the University of Tennessee’s APCSI Test Cell.

Conclusions:
•Testing has validated the functionality of the asymmetric tip seal system
•This provides a simple solution that will make the Legacy engine easier to manufacture and lower the cost of production
•Continued R&D is required to optimize the design but the test results demonstrate the design is sound thus removing it as a barrier to market entry

Flush-mount fuel injector nozzle

Conventional fuel injectors protrude into the combustion chamber of a conventional piston engine. This protrusion cannot be accommodated in the Legacy engine since the rotor and rotons pass the fuel injector while in contact with the housing. A flush-mount fuel injector nozzle was designed to address this issue. 


The flush-mount nozzle could be readily manufactured by a fuel injector manufacturer, modifying existing conventional injector nozzles was a cost effective way to demonstrate the viability of the concept. This modification required welding additional material onto the existing nozzle, machining the resulting nozzle to the required size and contour to match the housing, and producing the small holes to the size and orientation required for the GEN2.5B.

The flush-mount fuel injector nozzle was successfully developed and demonstrated at a fuel pressure of 12000 psi. Further development in combustion optimization requires continued research and development of the fuel injection system.

Induction and exhaust system optimization
The Legacy engine relies on scavenging of the exhaust to introduce the fresh charge, similar to a two-stroke conventional engine. Aspiration of the Legacy Engine is accomplished with ports, in an aspiration plate, rather than valves. This eliminates a complex subsystem, which lowers cost and improves reliability. To realize these benefits of port induction and exhaust, optimal intake and exhaust port design are absolutely critical to the performance of the engine.

PST has evaluated induction and exhaust performance of three aspiration plate designs to develop optimal inlet and exhaust port geometry for the Legacy GEN2.5 Advanced Concept Demonstrator. This effort was funded by NTRCI through a Department of Transportation grant awarded to PST. This effort resulted in an aspiration plate that optimizes the induction and exhaust for the GEN2.5B Legacy engine prototype, allowing for development and commercialization efforts to move forward. Further development is required; however, the results demonstrate that there are significant opportunities to increase the performance of the Legacy engine.

Next Steps – GEN002.5X Stand Alone Demonstrator

The next steps in the development process will leverage the existing GEN002.5 prototype. This will minimize both time and investment required to move the commercialization effort forward. The GEN002.5B can be modified to incorporate all the features necessary for “stand alone” operation. The first step is to produce a new housing with built in cooling feature and then integrating the subsystems such as a radiator, turbo/super charger, etc... into Gen002.5X. This will provide the information that will guild the design of the GEN003 prototype.


Thermal Management
Increased cooling demands are integral with unparalleled power density and high power to volume ratios. Providing the required cooling for such a compact engine design is a challenge that requires an innovative approach to both the cooling system and the various materials in the engine.

Combustion Optimization

Combustion optimization is the key to the increased efficiency predicted by our modeling and simulation. The unique geometry of the Legacy engine introduces thermodynamic processes that are unlike any other engine. This provides the opportunity to optimize the combustion processes and gain additional efficiencies beyond what is possible in a conventional engine. This is due to the manner in which the working volume changes as a function of the rotation of the engine.

The images (above) illustrate the unique thermodynamic processes of the Legacy engine.

Additionally, the combustion chamber is divided into two separate volumes, shown in the figures below. Fuel is injected into the leading volume and as the engine rotates, air is forced from the trailing volume into the leading volume creating high turbulence and improved mixing. Improved mixing will result in improved combustion and lower emissions. Software exists for conventional diesel engines, and it will be modified and enhanced for the unique geometry of the Legacy engine. The model will be calibrated, based on empirical data obtained from dynamometer evaluation of the prototypes, throughout the development phases of the project.  Because the software and expertise currently exist to address these issues, combustion optimization does not pose a risk to commercialization.

 

Controls

The prototype engine control system used thus far is fairly simple. It is capable of controlling the fuel injection parameters at single operating points. The injection timing and duration are real-time user inputs to the control software. For continued development of the Legacy engine, a more production-like control system must be developed that calculates and changes the control parameters based on sensor inputs.

However for the purposes of near term continuation of the development program the current engine control system can be used for the initial calibration of the proposed GEN002.5X.

Our Team:

Barton W. Watkins - Chairman/ Chief Executive Officer

Founder of Power Source Technologies, Inc. and Co-inventor of the Legacy engine, Mr. Bart Watkins currently holds five patents and has two patents pending, all of which pertain to the Legacy engine and are assigned to PST. He has senior management experience and strong team building capabilities. Mr. Watkins has brought together individuals with the technical, financial and legal expertise required to commercialize the Legacy engine. He is also President of Liz-Beth Fine Art, Inc., located in Knoxville, TN, since 1991. Liz-Beth Fine Art focuses on retail galleries, publishing and corporate art sales. Mr. Watkins served on the Board of Directors of the Dogwood Arts Festival, one of Tennessee’s largest cultural events from 2003-2007 and was named one of Knoxville, TN’s top executives under the age of forty in 2008.  In 2010, the National Transportation Research Center, Inc. (NTRCI) appointed Mr. Watkins Team Leader of a DOE funded effort investigating new seal technologies for the Legacy engine.

James F. Scothorn – Director/ Chief Financial Officer

President and CEO of Data & Organization Consultants, Inc., specializing in providing operational and financial services to the medical, food service, and building construction markets. Mr. Scothorn brings knowledge and expertise in manufacturing, contract management, money and banking, mergers, divestitures and operational management. He is the CEO of Tennessee Urology Associates, PLLC, and Chief Financial Officer of Aurora Lighting, Inc. He has a BS in Accounting, is a Certified Medical Planning Executive with the Medical Group Managers Association, Englewood, CO, and is the past president of the Tennessee Medical Group Management Association, Nashville, TN.

G. Cranwell Montgomery Esq. - Secretary and Chief Council

A member and shareholder of the law firm Baker, Doneldson, Berman, Caldwell, & Berkowitz. Mr. Montgomery is a   member of the Council on Foreign Relations and former Ambassador to the Sultanate of Oman. Mr. Montgomery served as Counsel to the Senate Majority Leader. He was in the United States Navy and resigned as a Lieutenant and has served in the United States Naval Reserve, where he attained rank of Captain. His memberships include the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, the American Bar Association, and the District of Columbia Bar Association. Mr. Montgomery has a BA from the University of Virginia   and and a JD from Vanderbilt University

Research & Development Team:

David K. Irick, PhD, PE – Chief Technical Officer

Professor Irick is also a faculty member of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at The University of Tennessee where he leads the automotive engineering research and teaching activities. He is a member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Society of Automotive Engineers, a senior member of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers and a licensed Professional Engineer in the State of Tennessee. Dr. Irick has over 30 years of industrial experience in design and manufacturing. He currently serves as Director of the UTK Graduate Automotive Technology Education Center. He also serves as faculty advisor for the University's participation in the U. S. Department of Energy's Advanced Vehicle Technology Competitions and serves as faculty advisor for the SAE student chapter. His teaching and research includes internal combustion engines, vehicle systems, computer integrated engineering and manufacturing.

Lawrence A. Hendrix - Vice President of Technology Development

Mr. Hendrix is a Co-inventor of the Legacy Engine. He has a very broad background in conceptual design and product development in electronics and mechanical designs. He has a BS in Electrical Engineering from the University of Tennessee and has worked for aerospace, research, manufacturing, and small business ventures.

Vitcheslav Naoumov, Ph.D., Dr. Sc. Professor, Central Connecticut State University

Dr. Naoumov is a professor in the Department of Engineering at Central Connecticut State University. He is a Professor and former Department Head in the Department of Engines, Institute of Aviation, Land Transport and Power Engineering, and the former Dean of the College of Aircraft and Rocket Engines at Kazan State Technical University in Kazan, Russia. He has authored three monographs (4th is in process), more than 80 journal articles, conference papers and proceedings, and more than 30 research contractor and scientific grant reports. Dr. Naoumov has over 20 years experience in the area of modeling and simulation of chemical non-equilibrium combustion and fluid flow in propulsion and power generation systems. He collaborated with SAAB in the development of powerful models for the simulation and prediction of combustion and nonequilibrium ionization in SI engines.

 Benjamin D. Nibali – Design Engineer

1995 B.S. Mechanical Engineering from Clemson University (Magna Cum Laude) Undergraduate Research in Controls Theory (Calhoun Honors College). Ten years in industrial machine design and engineering project management at Denso Manufacturing, Tennessee (Specialist thru Supervisor). Two years in aftermarket automotive product development at Keisler Engineering, Inc. (Product Engineering Manager)

 Aaron D. Carroll - Design Engineer

2007 B.S. Mechanical Engineering from Tennessee Tech University machine design concentration. One year in industrial machine design at Denso Manufacturing, Tennessee (Co-op). Three years in industrial machine design at Air & Hydraulic Equipment Inc. (Lead Mechanical Designer)

Benjamin M. Lamie - Design Engineer

2005 M.S. Mechanical Engineering from University of Tennessee Finite Element Analysis Concentration. Undergraduate Minor in Materials Science, Concentration in Structural/ Fluid Mechanics. Certified SolidWorks Professional, Certified CosmosWorks Technician-Advanced. One year in R&D of theoretical acoustic wave propagation using Finite Element Analysis model at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (Research Intern). Two years providing training and technical consultation services related to 3D CAD modeling and FEA software at ModernTech Mechanical Corp.

Technical/Business Network

PST management has committed to sound business and engineering practices by creating a research network and securing development partners. They include:

The National Transportation Research Center, Inc. (NTRCI) was incorporated in 1998 as a not for profit corporation with the goal of promoting the development and deployment of advanced transportation technologies through research, testing and commercialization for the benefit of the transportation industry and our transportation systems. In 2005, NTRCI was designated as a University Transportation Center with a strategic theme of Commercial Vehicle Safety, Security and Operational Efficiency. NTRCI pursues its programs through its research network of over 50 partners that include private industry, universities, governmental organizations (state, local and federal), national laboratories, and other not for profit corporations. NTRCI has demonstrated proven performance in identifying key team members, creating public-private partnerships, program management and financial management so that projects are completed on time and within budget.

NTRCI principals have over 60 years combined experience in wide ranging aspects of the transportation industry. Prior to joining NTRCI, the principals have been involved in management in all aspects of extensive private industry and governmental transportation programs valued up to $4 billion. At NTRCI, the principals have managed government and private industry vehicle test and development projects, private industry infrastructure projects and private industry engine research, development and test projects. NTRCI is currently under contract to the US Department of Energy to manage an aspect of PST’s advanced development on the Legacy engine.

The University of Tennessee’s Advanced Powertrains, Controls & System Integration (APCSI) automotive research lab has provided test facilities, as well as expertise in a number of areas. These include fuel injection, control systems, and combustion optimization.

ORT-E has worked with the aerospace, defense, energy, and automotive industries worldwide for more than four decades and is equipped to provide complex machining, tooling, and fabrication; manufacturing and assembly of special machines; and high-tech laser component manufacturing and maintenance. ORT-E will provide the prototype engines and hardware for the program.

Rewards:

 
 
 

 
 

Risks and challenges

The GEN002.5X will leverage everything we have learned and will result in a prototype that can be tested for long periods of time. To do this we need to design and fabricate a new housing to cool the engine cool during these tests. If we meet our stretch goals we will also package all of the subsystems making it a “stand-alone” prototype engine. The work that will be completed in this project will consist of bringing together the technologies that we have already validated, designing and fabricating a cooling jacket and integrating it into the Gen002.5B. The next step will be integrating “off the shelf” subsystems such as a radiator, turbo or super charger to make the Legacy Gen2.5X a "stand alone" prototype. This effort represents a lower technical risk than our previous projects because it does not involve the development of new technologies. However as with all research and development efforts, there is the risk of unforeseen challenges that may impede the effort. The commercialization of a new technology, in particular a new engine technology, is a very expensive and time consuming endeavor. It is a difficult task for the largest of companies and there is no guarantee that we will be successful in bringing the Legacy engine to market. This is why we have spent years developing a team of experts (See Bios above) and a research and business network (see above) that are second to none. We felt this was the perfect project to share because we are not working on proprietary designs so it will allow full disclosure of information in real time which will let our backers to have a front row seat throughout the project.

Future Technical Challenges:
The development of a functioning stand-alone engine is a critical step in the development of the Legacy engine, however there are additional challenges that must be addressed in order to commercialize the technology. These identified technical challenges will be addressed in the development of the Gen 003 and 004 prototypes. The development and testing of the Gen002.5X is critical to the design of the Gen003 and is the necessary next step.

Numerous other challenges exist but are typical of challenges that must be addressed in any internal combustion engine development program.
Key areas of required research and development include:

Induction and exhaust optimization
o The Legacy engine relies on scavenging of the exhaust to introduce the fresh charge, similar to a two-stroke conventional engine. Aspiration of the Legacy Engine is accomplished with ports rather than valves. This eliminates a complex subsystem, which lowers cost and improves reliability. To realize these benefits of port induction and exhaust, optimal intake and exhaust port design are absolutely critical to the performance of the engine.

Combustion Optimization
o Combustion optimization is the key to the increased efficiency predicted by our modeling and simulation. The unique geometry of the Legacy engine provides the opportunity to optimize the combustion processes and gain additional efficiencies beyond what is possible in a conventional engine. Additionally, the combustion chamber is divided into two separate volumes as illustrated in Figure 36 on page 27. Fuel is injected into the leading volume and as the engine rotates air is forced from the trailing volume into the leading volume creating high turbulence and improved mixing. Improved mixing will result in improved combustion and lower emissions.

Thermal management
Increased cooling demands are integral with unparalleled power density and high power to volume ratios. Providing the required cooling for such a compact engine design is an extreme challenge that requires an innovative approach to both the cooling system and the various materials in the engine.

Subsystem Development
Controls: The prototype engine control system used thus far is fairly simple. It is capable of controlling the fuel injection parameters at single operating points. The injection timing and duration are real-time user inputs to the control software. For continued development of the Legacy engine, a more production-like control system must be developed that calculates and changes the control parameters based on sensor inputs.

Fuel injection: While the flush-mount fuel injector nozzle was successfully developed and demonstrated on this project, further development in combustion optimization requires research and development of the fuel injection system. Particularly, emissions compliance for compression ignition engines depends heavily on optimizing the injection parameters (timing, duration, pressure, orifice size, etc.).

Conclusions
Successful completion of research and development in the listed areas will lead to validation of the predicted improvements in efficiency and will provide the foundation necessary for commercialization the Legacy engine.

We are a group of highly dedicated individuals committed to making the Legacy engine technology available to everyone. Our team consists of experts in engine design and development as well highly qualified people in business development and financial management.  This team is the backbone of the company and has made our development to date possible. For over five years our team has invested their time, energy and money into the Legacy technology. With your help we can take the next critical step! Scroll down for detailed Bios.

Why We Need Your Help:
We need your help to build the GEN002.5X prototype! This is the next and most critical step in getting the Legacy engine to market. Over the past few years we have successfully addressed many of the technical challenges related to the Legacy engine. Now we need to bring it all together. The GEN002.5X will leverage everything we have learned and will result in a prototype that can be tested for long periods of time. To do this we need to design and fabricate a new housing that can keep the engine cool during these tests. We can do this in less than a year but we need you help to make it happen!

Fluid flow and heat transfer analysis of Gen002.5X housing
The following shows the design and fabrication of the Gen2.5B housing. This is similar to our project but much more simple. The Gen2.5X housing design will incorporate information from our fluid flow and heat transfer analysis (shown above) to insure it can dissipate the heat created during combustion testing.

Design Drawings for the Gen002.5B Housing

Fabrication of Gen002.5B Housing
Stretch Goals:
If we are able to raise $250,000 then we will be able to take the next step in the development process by making Legacy Gen002.5X a "stand alone" prototype. We will achieve this by integrating the subsystems such as a radiator, turbo/super charger, etc... By making the Legacy Gen002.5X “stand-alone” prototype we will have taken the next major step in our development.
Of course it we are SUPER successful in our effort then we will be able to achieve more than this so please help us as much as you can!
What You Get!
We have all kinds of unique and historical rewards for you and many of them are exclusives to this effort. The best thing we have to offer is a front row seat to this exciting project. All of our backers will have access to information as we move forward but some of you will get to see the technical data and even see tests streamed in real time. To learn more about this please read the letter from our CEO below.
Whether you give a little or a lot we want to thank you in advance for helping us. We believe the Legacy engine will have a significant and positive impact for everyone. Those that help make it happen deserve not only our gratitude but also something to commemorate their efforts toward making this project happen. The rewards are listed on the bar to the left but we also have detailed descriptions and pictures below. So just scroll down to see them. There is a lot of technical info below so just keep going and you will find them!
A Letter From Our CEO
 

 
The Legacy engine technology:

How Does it Work?
 This animation shows the basic operation of the Legacy engine as well as it major components and how they function.
 
The Legacy engine is low speed high torque planetary engine, comprised of a central rotor and orbiting elements, named rotons. The figure below depicts the Legacy engine configuration, with major components labeled. It also illustrates the combustion processes occurring symmetrically on the three faces of each of the three rotons. These processes enable the Legacy engine to execute nine complete thermodynamic cycles in a single revolution.
 

Innovative Combustion Geometry: The geometry of the Legacy engine increases the volume of the combustion chamber with shaft rotation differently than conventional piston/crankshaft engines. This yields increased efficiency from the air standard model (described below), by generating higher pressures during the expansion process.
Beyond the gains in efficiency predicted by the air-standard models, the engine geometry also provides a unique combustion chamber and unique combustion process. As the roton reaches the minimum volume position, the working combustion volume is divided into: 1) the leading volume; and 2) the trailing volume, as shown in the adjacent figure.
Fuel is injected into the leading volume after volume division, continuing as the roton moves across the housing peak. The trailing volume contains only compressed air, forced into the leading volume as the roton continues past the housing peak. The compressed air is highly turbulent, being forced through the narrow clearance between the roton and the housing.
This Legacy engine combustion process is enhanced in two ways: 1) the fuel/air mixture in the leading volume is closer to the stoichiometric requirement, enhancing ignition, while the overall operating mixture remains lean (typical of compression ignition); and 2) the highly turbulent air, forced from the trailing volume, promotes mixing, resulting in more efficient combustion.
Inherent Rotary Motion: The Legacy engine forces combustion pressure to be applied directly to the output shaft as torque, eliminating the reciprocating-to-rotary mechanism in conventional piston/crankshaft engines. This increases efficiency by avoiding friction loss from thrust loading of the pistons. It also yields improved vibration characteristics and reduces the engine part count.
Aspiration Simplicity: Aspiration of the Legacy engine is accomplished with ports rather than valves. This eliminates a complex subsystem, lowering cost and improving reliability.
Engine Component Simplicity: Many Legacy engine components have simple design geometry, surfaces of revolution or extruded profiles. These simple shapes allow the application of advanced ceramic and composite materials, which are less easily used in the complex geometry of conventional engines. The Legacy engine can be configured as “shaft-horizontal” or “shaft-vertical”, increasing design latitude of downstream power transmission components, and packaging options.
Thermodynamic AnalysisThe University of Tennessee has performed a thermodynamic analysis using an air-standard cycle with Wiebe function heat addition. This analysis of the Legacy engine was also compared to a crankshaft engine with the same displacement and compression ratio and operating with the same emissions-compliant fuel calibration.

The figure above shows modeling results for this comparison. We predict an increase in efficiency of approximately sixteen percent (16%). ConclusionThermodynamic analysis of the Legacy engine predicts – • An increase in thermal efficiency of approximately 16% over an equivalent crankshaft engine• Enhanced mixing of the fuel and air due to the unique combustion chamber and unique combustion process should increase the overall efficiency gain to greater than 20%• Additional increases in efficiencies can be achieved through continued development and by employing state-of-the-art subsystems currently available.


Development Efforts To Date

PST has maintained a scientific approach throughout the research and development efforts pertaining to the Legacy engine. To date we have designed, fabricated and tested four iterations of the Legacy engine and have successfully addressed many of the primary technical challenges we face in commercializing the technology. Additional technical challenges exist, but are typical of challenges that must be addressed in any internal combustion engine development programs, and are considered to represent a low level of risk. The following outlines the progress to date. Testing and evaluation of the Legacy engine are conducted at the University of Tennessee’s Advanced Powertrains, Controls & System Integration (APCSI) automotive research laboratory.

GEN001 Proof of Geometry

The GEN001 was tested at a rotational speed of 250 rpm, less than typical cranking speed, to avoid damaging the prototype. The data confirmed that seals can function across pressure boundary dividing combustion chamber.

GEN002 Proof of Concept
The GEN002 validated the viability of the Legacy engine and provided a clear path forward. Lessons learned guided further development.


Click image to see the Gen002 being tested

GEN002.5 Advanced Concept Demonstrator

In the fourth quarter of 2010, PST entered into a contract with the National Transportation Research Center, Inc. (NTRCI) to investigate an asymmetric tip seal system and a flush mount fuel injector nozzle for use in the Legacy engine. This effort, funded by the Department of Energy, has validated the functionality of the asymmetric tip seal system as well as the flush mount fuel injector nozzles. The asymmetric tip seal provides a simple solution that will make the Legacy engine easier to manufacture and lower the cost of production. Continued R&D is required to optimize the design but the test results indicate the design is sound and provides the solution to this technical challenge.


Data Aquisition

Fuel pump and Injectors
The roton tip seal represented the key technical challenge to the commercialization of the Legacy engine however; a solution to this challenge has been developed and successfully tested. 

The asymmetric tip seal system was integrated into the GEN002, now designated the GEN002.5A & B.


The Gen002.5 was tested at the University of Tennessee’s APCSI Test Cell.
Conclusions: •Testing has validated the functionality of the asymmetric tip seal system •This provides a simple solution that will make the Legacy engine easier to manufacture and lower the cost of production•Continued R&D is required to optimize the design but the test results demonstrate the design is sound thus removing it as a barrier to market entryFlush-mount fuel injector nozzle 
Conventional fuel injectors protrude into the combustion chamber of a conventional piston engine. This protrusion cannot be accommodated in the Legacy engine since the rotor and rotons pass the fuel injector while in contact with the housing. A flush-mount fuel injector nozzle was designed to address this issue. 

The flush-mount nozzle could be readily manufactured by a fuel injector manufacturer, modifying existing conventional injector nozzles was a cost effective way to demonstrate the viability of the concept. This modification required welding additional material onto the existing nozzle, machining the resulting nozzle to the required size and contour to match the housing, and producing the small holes to the size and orientation required for the GEN2.5B.

The flush-mount fuel injector nozzle was successfully developed and demonstrated at a fuel pressure of 12000 psi. Further development in combustion optimization requires continued research and development of the fuel injection system.
Induction and exhaust system optimizationThe Legacy engine relies on scavenging of the exhaust to introduce the fresh charge, similar to a two-stroke conventional engine. Aspiration of the Legacy Engine is accomplished with ports, in an aspiration plate, rather than valves. This eliminates a complex subsystem, which lowers cost and improves reliability. To realize these benefits of port induction and exhaust, optimal intake and exhaust port design are absolutely critical to the performance of the engine.

PST has evaluated induction and exhaust performance of three aspiration plate designs to develop optimal inlet and exhaust port geometry for the Legacy GEN2.5 Advanced Concept Demonstrator. This effort was funded by NTRCI through a Department of Transportation grant awarded to PST. This effort resulted in an aspiration plate that optimizes the induction and exhaust for the GEN2.5B Legacy engine prototype, allowing for development and commercialization efforts to move forward. Further development is required; however, the results demonstrate that there are significant opportunities to increase the performance of the Legacy engine.
Next Steps – GEN002.5X Stand Alone Demonstrator
The next steps in the development process will leverage the existing GEN002.5 prototype. This will minimize both time and investment required to move the commercialization effort forward. The GEN002.5B can be modified to incorporate all the features necessary for “stand alone” operation. The first step is to produce a new housing with built in cooling feature and then integrating the subsystems such as a radiator, turbo/super charger, etc... into Gen002.5X. This will provide the information that will guild the design of the GEN003 prototype.
Thermal ManagementIncreased cooling demands are integral with unparalleled power density and high power to volume ratios. Providing the required cooling for such a compact engine design is a challenge that requires an innovative approach to both the cooling system and the various materials in the engine.

Combustion Optimization
Combustion optimization is the key to the increased efficiency predicted by our modeling and simulation. The unique geometry of the Legacy engine introduces thermodynamic processes that are unlike any other engine. This provides the opportunity to optimize the combustion processes and gain additional efficiencies beyond what is possible in a conventional engine. This is due to the manner in which the working volume changes as a function of the rotation of the engine.

The images (above) illustrate the unique thermodynamic processes of the Legacy engine. 
Additionally, the combustion chamber is divided into two separate volumes, shown in the figures below. Fuel is injected into the leading volume and as the engine rotates, air is forced from the trailing volume into the leading volume creating high turbulence and improved mixing. Improved mixing will result in improved combustion and lower emissions. Software exists for conventional diesel engines, and it will be modified and enhanced for the unique geometry of the Legacy engine. The model will be calibrated, based on empirical data obtained from dynamometer evaluation of the prototypes, throughout the development phases of the project.  Because the software and expertise currently exist to address these issues, combustion optimization does not pose a risk to commercialization.
 


Controls
The prototype engine control system used thus far is fairly simple. It is capable of controlling the fuel injection parameters at single operating points. The injection timing and duration are real-time user inputs to the control software. For continued development of the Legacy engine, a more production-like control system must be developed that calculates and changes the control parameters based on sensor inputs.
However for the purposes of near term continuation of the development program the current engine control system can be used for the initial calibration of the proposed GEN002.5X.
Our Team:
Barton W. Watkins - Chairman/ Chief Executive Officer
Founder of Power Source Technologies, Inc. and Co-inventor of the Legacy engine, Mr. Bart Watkins currently holds five patents and has two patents pending, all of which pertain to the Legacy engine and are assigned to PST. He has senior management experience and strong team building capabilities. Mr. Watkins has brought together individuals with the technical, financial and legal expertise required to commercialize the Legacy engine. He is also President of Liz-Beth Fine Art, Inc., located in Knoxville, TN, since 1991. Liz-Beth Fine Art focuses on retail galleries, publishing and corporate art sales. Mr. Watkins served on the Board of Directors of the Dogwood Arts Festival, one of Tennessee’s largest cultural events from 2003-2007 and was named one of Knoxville, TN’s top executives under the age of forty in 2008.  In 2010, the National Transportation Research Center, Inc. (NTRCI) appointed Mr. Watkins Team Leader of a DOE funded effort investigating new seal technologies for the Legacy engine.
James F. Scothorn – Director/ Chief Financial Officer
President and CEO of Data & Organization Consultants, Inc., specializing in providing operational and financial services to the medical, food service, and building construction markets. Mr. Scothorn brings knowledge and expertise in manufacturing, contract management, money and banking, mergers, divestitures and operational management. He is the CEO of Tennessee Urology Associates, PLLC, and Chief Financial Officer of Aurora Lighting, Inc. He has a BS in Accounting, is a Certified Medical Planning Executive with the Medical Group Managers Association, Englewood, CO, and is the past president of the Tennessee Medical Group Management Association, Nashville, TN.
G. Cranwell Montgomery Esq. - Secretary and Chief Council
A member and shareholder of the law firm Baker, Doneldson, Berman, Caldwell, & Berkowitz. Mr. Montgomery is a   member of the Council on Foreign Relations and former Ambassador to the Sultanate of Oman. Mr. Montgomery served as Counsel to the Senate Majority Leader. He was in the United States Navy and resigned as a Lieutenant and has served in the United States Naval Reserve, where he attained rank of Captain. His memberships include the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, the American Bar Association, and the District of Columbia Bar Association. Mr. Montgomery has a BA from the University of Virginia   and and a JD from Vanderbilt University
Research & Development Team: 
David K. Irick, PhD, PE – Chief Technical Officer
Professor Irick is also a faculty member of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at The University of Tennessee where he leads the automotive engineering research and teaching activities. He is a member of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Society of Automotive Engineers, a senior member of the Society of Manufacturing Engineers and a licensed Professional Engineer in the State of Tennessee. Dr. Irick has over 30 years of industrial experience in design and manufacturing. He currently serves as Director of the UTK Graduate Automotive Technology Education Center. He also serves as faculty advisor for the University's participation in the U. S. Department of Energy's Advanced Vehicle Technology Competitions and serves as faculty advisor for the SAE student chapter. His teaching and research includes internal combustion engines, vehicle systems, computer integrated engineering and manufacturing.
Lawrence A. Hendrix - Vice President of Technology Development 
Mr. Hendrix is a Co-inventor of the Legacy Engine. He has a very broad background in conceptual design and product development in electronics and mechanical designs. He has a BS in Electrical Engineering from the University of Tennessee and has worked for aerospace, research, manufacturing, and small business ventures.
Vitcheslav Naoumov, Ph.D., Dr. Sc. Professor, Central Connecticut State University
Dr. Naoumov is a professor in the Department of Engineering at Central Connecticut State University. He is a Professor and former Department Head in the Department of Engines, Institute of Aviation, Land Transport and Power Engineering, and the former Dean of the College of Aircraft and Rocket Engines at Kazan State Technical University in Kazan, Russia. He has authored three monographs (4th is in process), more than 80 journal articles, conference papers and proceedings, and more than 30 research contractor and scientific grant reports. Dr. Naoumov has over 20 years experience in the area of modeling and simulation of chemical non-equilibrium combustion and fluid flow in propulsion and power generation systems. He collaborated with SAAB in the development of powerful models for the simulation and prediction of combustion and nonequilibrium ionization in SI engines.
 Benjamin D. Nibali – Design Engineer 
1995 B.S. Mechanical Engineering from Clemson University (Magna Cum Laude) Undergraduate Research in Controls Theory (Calhoun Honors College). Ten years in industrial machine design and engineering project management at Denso Manufacturing, Tennessee (Specialist thru Supervisor). Two years in aftermarket automotive product development at Keisler Engineering, Inc. (Product Engineering Manager)
 Aaron D. Carroll - Design Engineer 
2007 B.S. Mechanical Engineering from Tennessee Tech University machine design concentration. One year in industrial machine design at Denso Manufacturing, Tennessee (Co-op). Three years in industrial machine design at Air & Hydraulic Equipment Inc. (Lead Mechanical Designer)
Benjamin M. Lamie - Design Engineer 
2005 M.S. Mechanical Engineering from University of Tennessee Finite Element Analysis Concentration. Undergraduate Minor in Materials Science, Concentration in Structural/ Fluid Mechanics. Certified SolidWorks Professional, Certified CosmosWorks Technician-Advanced. One year in R&D of theoretical acoustic wave propagation using Finite Element Analysis model at Oak Ridge National Laboratory (Research Intern). Two years providing training and technical consultation services related to 3D CAD modeling and FEA software at ModernTech Mechanical Corp.
Technical/Business Network
PST management has committed to sound business and engineering practices by creating a research network and securing development partners. They include:

The National Transportation Research Center, Inc. (NTRCI) was incorporated in 1998 as a not for profit corporation with the goal of promoting the development and deployment of advanced transportation technologies through research, testing and commercialization for the benefit of the transportation industry and our transportation systems. In 2005, NTRCI was designated as a University Transportation Center with a strategic theme of Commercial Vehicle Safety, Security and Operational Efficiency. NTRCI pursues its programs through its research network of over 50 partners that include private industry, universities, governmental organizations (state, local and federal), national laboratories, and other not for profit corporations. NTRCI has demonstrated proven performance in identifying key team members, creating public-private partnerships, program management and financial management so that projects are completed on time and within budget.
NTRCI principals have over 60 years combined experience in wide ranging aspects of the transportation industry. Prior to joining NTRCI, the principals have been involved in management in all aspects of extensive private industry and governmental transportation programs valued up to $4 billion. At NTRCI, the principals have managed government and private industry vehicle test and development projects, private industry infrastructure projects and private industry engine research, development and test projects. NTRCI is currently under contract to the US Department of Energy to manage an aspect of PST’s advanced development on the Legacy engine.

The University of Tennessee’s Advanced Powertrains, Controls & System Integration (APCSI) automotive research lab has provided test facilities, as well as expertise in a number of areas. These include fuel injection, control systems, and combustion optimization.

ORT-E has worked with the aerospace, defense, energy, and automotive industries worldwide for more than four decades and is equipped to provide complex machining, tooling, and fabrication; manufacturing and assembly of special machines; and high-tech laser component manufacturing and maintenance. ORT-E will provide the prototype engines and hardware for the program.
Rewards:

 



 


 






 


 

Risks and challenges
The GEN002.5X will leverage everything we have learned and will result in a prototype that can be tested for long periods of time. To do this we need to design and fabricate a new housing to cool the engine cool during these tests. If we meet our stretch goals we will also package all of the subsystems making it a “stand-alone” prototype engine. The work that will be completed in this project will consist of bringing together the technologies that we have already validated, designing and fabricating a cooling jacket and integrating it into the Gen002.5B. The next step will be integrating “off the shelf” subsystems such as a radiator, turbo or super charger to make the Legacy Gen2.5X a "stand alone" prototype. This effort represents a lower technical risk than our previous projects because it does not involve the development of new technologies. However as with all research and development efforts, there is the risk of unforeseen challenges that may impede the effort. The commercialization of a new technology, in particular a new engine technology, is a very expensive and time consuming endeavor. It is a difficult task for the largest of companies and there is no guarantee that we will be successful in bringing the Legacy engine to market. This is why we have spent years developing a team of experts (See Bios above) and a research and business network (see above) that are second to none. We felt this was the perfect project to share because we are not working on proprietary designs so it will allow full disclosure of information in real time which will let our backers to have a front row seat throughout the project.
Future Technical Challenges: The development of a functioning stand-alone engine is a critical step in the development of the Legacy engine, however there are additional challenges that must be addressed in order to commercialize the technology. These identified technical challenges will be addressed in the development of the Gen 003 and 004 prototypes. The development and testing of the Gen002.5X is critical to the design of the Gen003 and is the necessary next step.
Numerous other challenges exist but are typical of challenges that must be addressed in any internal combustion engine development program. Key areas of required research and development include:
Induction and exhaust optimization o The Legacy engine relies on scavenging of the exhaust to introduce the fresh charge, similar to a two-stroke conventional engine. Aspiration of the Legacy Engine is accomplished with ports rather than valves. This eliminates a complex subsystem, which lowers cost and improves reliability. To realize these benefits of port induction and exhaust, optimal intake and exhaust port design are absolutely critical to the performance of the engine.
Combustion Optimization o Combustion optimization is the key to the increased efficiency predicted by our modeling and simulation. The unique geometry of the Legacy engine provides the opportunity to optimize the combustion processes and gain additional efficiencies beyond what is possible in a conventional engine. Additionally, the combustion chamber is divided into two separate volumes as illustrated in Figure 36 on page 27. Fuel is injected into the leading volume and as the engine rotates air is forced from the trailing volume into the leading volume creating high turbulence and improved mixing. Improved mixing will result in improved combustion and lower emissions.
Thermal management Increased cooling demands are integral with unparalleled power density and high power to volume ratios. Providing the required cooling for such a compact engine design is an extreme challenge that requires an innovative approach to both the cooling system and the various materials in the engine.
Subsystem Development Controls: The prototype engine control system used thus far is fairly simple. It is capable of controlling the fuel injection parameters at single operating points. The injection timing and duration are real-time user inputs to the control software. For continued development of the Legacy engine, a more production-like control system must be developed that calculates and changes the control parameters based on sensor inputs.
Fuel injection: While the flush-mount fuel injector nozzle was successfully developed and demonstrated on this project, further development in combustion optimization requires research and development of the fuel injection system. Particularly, emissions compliance for compression ignition engines depends heavily on optimizing the injection parameters (timing, duration, pressure, orifice size, etc.).
Conclusions Successful completion of research and development in the listed areas will lead to validation of the predicted improvements in efficiency and will provide the foundation necessary for commercialization the Legacy engine.

story:
PCDock is not just a monitor stand.

                     Buy it on Lanq official Store

中文 (简体) | 中文 (繁體) | Deutsch | Italiano | 日本語 | Français | Español | 한국어 |  Ρусский | Dansk | Srpski

 

 

Ready to meet the desktop tool that hacks your PC experience to a superior level?

Upgrade your setup with PCDock! It will transform your desktop into a more secure and convenient environment. Especially if you plan to DIY your PC or save money on a board without Bluetooth or WiFi, it will be compensated for the lack of features you might have on the rest of your PC.

 

 

Tired of memorizing a bunch of pin codes

 

Hard to find a stable Wifi adapter when your PC doesn't have a WiFi card

 

Sick of dealing with cables

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Less Typing. More Tapping.

 

 

LANQ PCDock provides a speedy and safe entry in 0.15s with a unique Fingerprint module supported by Windows Hello biometric authorization. No need to memorize and type your password every time you start PC.

 

 

Able to register different fingerprint sets to make it possible to switch accounts in a split second.

 

Reimagined WiFi Performance

 

Unless you have Ethernet ports where your gaming PC will dominate, you'll need a WiFi card to connect it to the internet. PCDock is like a USB WiFi adapter that lets you connect wirelessly to networks, even if your device doesn't have a wireless network card.

 

 

 

LANQ provides a built-in dual-band (2.4G/5.8G) WiFi Adapter with high-performance speed up to 1200Mbps and remains stable no matter if it is a single task or multitasks downloading. It is strong enough to support buffer-free streaming and hotspot sharing.

 

The Wireless Way to Make Your Day.

 

 

For gaming: It’s time to enjoy games using wireless devices without any noticeable lag. LANQ PCDock offers advanced built-in Bluetooth that allows up to 10 devices to connect within 20 meters barrier-free transmission range.

 

 

For privacy: Enable the Microsoft Dynamic Lock to prevent any access without permission. The system has the authority to lock your PC immediately when you left more than 1 minute with any paired device.

 

 

For audio: No 3.5mm jack needed to play and enjoy lossless audio thanks to Qualcomm aptX technology.

 

Just Sit. Everything Is Within Reach.

 

 

Features a built-in fast charger and USB Hub on the side, saying goodbye to the days of reaching down to plug in a USB stick. With the effortless wireless charger and 4 Type-C/A ports to charge phones across all IOS/Android platforms. Multiple port types with file transfer rates up to 5Gbps.

  • *USB Type-C 3.2 Gen 1 x2 (5Gbps transfer rate)
  • *USB Type-A 3.2 Gen 1 x2 (5Gbps transfer rate)
  • 15W Wireless Charging
  • 15W Fast Wire Charging (Single Port Charging)

*(also named as USB 3.1 Gen 1 and USB 3.0)

 

 

 

​

Comfort and Neat

 

 

Lift your monitor to 83mm high so to lower the chance of suffering from a sore neck. It also comes with proper storage space for your keyboard and mouse.

 

 

Your Setup. Your Way!

 

Three sizes, more possibilities, no compromises! For fun, both the LANQ PCDock Pro & Pro Max are designed with an RGB light under the desk to make sure you get your vibe just right!

Got a mounted monitor? Then our LANQ PCDock Standard is for you. Simple but professional, small but powerful.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

We are geeks, players and creators that aim to build a whole new electronic experience. All the time, we are seeking is a product that makes everyone feel passionate about it. Not just selling something, thinking and feeling as a consumer is always considered a priority. There’s no way to create anything if we have no interest in it.

 

 

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

 

This is LANQ's first campaign, but we are confident to guarantee 100% delivery and contribution will be there. We stand out and aim to change the normal electronic product standard. For the manufactory, we have already begun production and make sure everything is going well.

Therefore please understand that the global pandemic might influence the delivery speed. We will let you know if any unexpected circumstances occur. We will provide you with a professional after-sale support service to help with problem fixing.

story: -

I am a mom of three kids who has become tired of being vigilant to look out for products made in China.  So, I'm going to start a company where there is not that worry. 

We are a start-up that is need of everything from logo design to phones to inventory to a web site.  We will be selling upscale children's clothing such as Lacoste and 7 for all Mankind.  We will be selling classic children's toys such as wooden trains and building products from companies such as Maple Landmark Woodcraft and Roytoy, respectively. 

We will have theme boxes for children.  There are busy parents out there who would like to get their children age-appropriate toys and books, but just don't have time to research.  We've done the work for you.  Each month through 36 months, there will be age-appropriate boxes to help with the emotional and cognitive develop of the child.  There will also be theme boxes for older kids as well. 

We will also be employing adults with developmental disabilities.  There are so many who want to work and are so kind that it's a win/win in my book. 

You will be helping kids stay safe from harmful products and developmentally disabled adults become independent. 

I need $25,000 to purchase inventory, rent a space, get a merchant account, develop a web site, design a log, and have money to pay employees until we start getting paid. 

We will also be partnering with a non-profit called Invisible String.  Theme boxes can be purchased from The Pineapple Shop to give to Invisible String to be donated to families. 

If you are interested in investing more, I am offering 1 year term return of 15% (100,000 = 115,000 at the end of the year term) plus .5% of the net profits for the year for each 10,000 invested.  You can contact me at thepineappleshop@yahoo.com.

story:
Love HOWie do it!

Remember your first HOW Conference? It blew your mind with amazing sessions and topics. You discovered that these are your people, who then became your extended family. You came home ready to design the world. Now, as a HOWie (even if you've only been once), you have the opportunity to share that HOW love by helping to send a newbie to HOW. Let's show HOWie do it!

Each donation helps, no matter the size—even $10. Every person who donates will get special recognition at the conference, and a little something to add onto your HOW badge that designates you as someone who's donated. Even if you're unable to contribute, help us spread the word to other HOW regulars who know the long-lasting value of attending.

HOW is not the least expensive conference (*cough*cough*)—but it is the BEST conference for learning, growing, and connecting. For a Big Ticket (entrance to all five conferences), airfare into Boston, and a hotel room for five nights, we're hoping to raise $2500. 

But wait, the goal up there is only $500, right? That's because hosting the fundraiser here on Indiegogo means that they get 9% if we don't meet our goal, and 4% if we do. (We'd like to give as much money as possible to the grant recipient, instead of this web service.)

Thank you in advance for your generous contribution! 

(This grant is organized by your fellow HOWies, and not affiliated with F+W Media.)

story:
Short Summary

  • We're HackRVA - We make great things with a community of inspiring people!
  •  HackRVA members will be able to use this awesome tool for creative design, rapid prototyping, open hardware projects, or whatever their heart's desire.
  • We'll also be able to make our own furniture, work benches, equipment, and signs for the space.
  • Support our initiative to crowdfund this 4'x4' CNC Router. It will complete HackRVA's  "tri-fecta of maker tools" (3D Printer, Laser Cutter, CNC Router).
  • Check out some more videos of the tool in action.
  • HackRVA and Richmond take another step in joining the digital design revolution!

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise $1200 to make this happen. We'd like to get to $1700 to cover an upgraded spindle, tooling, and near term maintenance costs.

  • $25 contributors and up will have their names CNC'd into a glorious mantel that will be fitted to the the machine's superstructure for all to revel in!
  • $100 contributors will be invited to our initial training events to learn the mysterious ways of creating with CNC!
  • All contributors receive a cool memento made on the CNC, we just have to figure out what that's going to be. Possibly a stylized HackRVA mini-sign for the home. (We're not mailing them out, so whatever it is, come to the space to get it. Or even better, we give you the design file and material, you make the machine go.)
  • All HackRVA members regardless of contribution get access to a great tool with tech support and training for a fraction of the tool's cost.


    Impact

    HackRVA members will have a greater ability to make new things. Things which can be designed with digital tools such as CAD software and brought to reality with much more ease than traditional methods.

    We will also be able to contribute back to the maker community at large across the web with greater impact. With the power of a CNC router we can create open source objects for a wide range of applications. 

    Everyday objects, artistic endeavors, and technological artifacts (like quadcopter frames) can be cut out of materials like plastic, wood, cardboard, carbon-fiber, and even some light metals like aluminum.

    And they can be shared and re-made by other hobbyists, makers, and makerspaces wherever they may be by downloading our designs. Design it once, and anyone with a CNC will be able to make as many copies as they want to use or improve upon.

    Below are some websites for open source design with CNC routers, many of which allow anyone to create or download files to start cutting right away (kinda like Thingiverse does for 3D printing):

    http://www.sketchchair.cc/
    http://www.wikihouse.cc/
    http://grabcad.com/
    AtFAB
    Thingiverse (tag: lasercut- many laser-able things can be CNC routed)
    Ponoko
    Skethup 3D Warehouse

    Using the Tool

    There are 3 basic workflows for using the tool:
    • Download a G-Code file. Run it in the CNC Router.
    • Download a CAD or vector design file. Convert the file to G-Code using a G-Code converter.
    • Draw your own design file using a CAD program or a vector drawing program like Inkscape, then run that through a G-Code converter.

    If you know 3D printing, it's a similar workflow. Sometimes you just put a file straight into the Makerbot, other times you design something yourself and run that through.

    There's a few added things to learn about CNC routing such as tool diameter, feeds &speeds, and cut depth. But any of our savvy folks at the space can learn the basics of this tool in an about hour or less.

    We're also in the process of creating a Digital Design Workstation at the space so that all the needed software for CNC, Lasercutting, and 3D printing will be on a single maintained computer and at the ready.

    The CNC itself will live in the back of our FabLab  (aka Tool Room). We've already constructed much of the wooden platform it will be mounted too as well as the rolling storage units that will go under it.

    Training for this tool will be required to ensure it's longevity. It's possible to damage a CNC router without the proper know-how.

    Risks & Challenges

    • We have tested the tool to ensure it works. But like all complex tools it's possible that the machine will have issues from time to time, break down, or eventually die on us. 
    • That being said, we view the CNC Mogul as an affordable option for a much requested item to add to the HackRVA arsenal of makery tools. From our research at places like CNC zone, people who've owned the CNC Mogul are satisfied with it's performance/size/cost ratio.

story:
Revolutionizing the System for Creative People

Algorithms over Ideas? What's easy to sell over what's good? Quantity over Quality? Money, Brands and everything else over the People who actually create? People think that's how it is.
We say, screw that.
Let's put Creativity over everything!

 

 

HERE'S THE APP

  1. FREE DOWNLOAD (Android & iOS)
  2. CREATE A PROFILE - ARTIST or COMPANY
  3. APPLY & GET BOOKED for Jobs near you 
  4. FIND ARTISTS for Productions & Projects​
  5. REVIEW APPLICATIONS
  6. KEEP TRACK of your Bookings
  7. BOOKING REPORTS via Email
  8. GIVE FEEDBACK to ensure great Quality
  9. CONNECT your Social-Media, CV-Upload and more... get the app!

 

 

UP & RUNNING

Get it now and always be first to try out new Functions & Features along the Way. It's ready for you to use with the Functions listed above fully implemented.

​

 

 

BEETREE & YOU

Since the official Release on February 20th 2020 we've received amazing Feedback from our almost 1'000 creative Users. Because of that we want to take Action, to implement new Functions and to fully enhance the Quality of the App, so it works exactly the way you want it to. Here's how it works:

 

 

When you purchase your Perk, you help us bring you these Tools:

THE ACADEMY (New App Page):
Become a Mentor and share your Creation (Podcast, Tutorial, Blog, Vlog, Concepts, etc.)

FINDER (New App Page):
Search for Artists or Companies near you

COMMUNITY (Tool):
Connect your professional Network & your Friends to keep your most important Contacts organized

PROJECT MANAGER (Tool):
Create a Project, let the App find everything you need, manage Bookings

DARK MODE (Function)
- Idea by Ambassador @therealmarque

GUEST PROFILE (Function)
Non-Artists can register and book Artists for Projects & Gigs

GALLERY (Tool)
Organize your Photos & Videos

COLOR MODE (Function)
- Idea by Ambassador @corteskimberly_

BUSINESS CREATOR (Tool)
Manage Candidates, Payments, Ads & Projects
- Idea by Ambassador @jorgedesilvaofficial

DIRECT PAYMENT (Tool)
No more back-and-forth; get paid directly after your Job is done

MESSENGER (Tool)
Keep in Touch with your Network via In-App Chat

MENTORS PROGRAM (Tool)
- Idea by Ambassador @gogalit

TOUR SUPPORT (Tool)
Our professional Team of Lawyers, Agents, Doctors assist you with Travel, VISA, Health & Emergency

VERIFICATION BADGE
Stand out as a Pro with your blue Profile Badge

GENERAL IMPROVEMENTS (Design, Flow, Filter, Profiles, Languages, etc.) ...and many more!

 

 

YOU DECIDE

In the Comment-Section you can find each Function listed separately. Simply click the Like-Button on your most desired Function and tell your Friends to do the same. The Function with the most Likes is where we put our Focus first.
Go for it and shape the App!

 

 



RECENT APP UPDATE

Nov. 25, 2020 - Version 1.3.0
Hold my drink, WE ARE WORLDWIDE!

What's new? Yes, worldwide available, tell a friend right now. Oh, and this is good, swipe down to refresh a page, change your contact email address, and company accounts can now visit profiles too. Also, your account stage name sounds funny. Sorry, not sorry. Creativity is key. Can‘t create alone? Find people here. You like that? Rate our app and keep it buzzing.
 

 

 

TESTIMONIALS

"SAVE YOUR SPOT ON THE TO BE LARGEST CREATIVE PLATFORM."
- Seven (@sevenmusic)

"WORKING HAS NEVER BEEN EASIER FOR ME. THANK YOU FOR GIVING US ARTISTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WHENEVER AND WHEREVER WE ARE!"
- Melzie (@callmemelzie)

"SUCH A USEFUL APP WHICH REALLY HELPS ARTISTS TO FIND JOBS!"
- Fabienne S.

"I'M REALLY HAPPY ABOUT THIS APP! SUCH A GREAT TOOL FOR ARTISTS UND CREATIVE PEOPLE TO EXCHANGE KNOWLEDGE & CREATE WORK. SUPER EASY TO USE!"
- Nina T.


 

 

 

1 MILLION TREES

PLANT YOUR TREE NOW
No, not in your Backyard. With every purchased Perk that includes a Tree-Planting, you are planting a Tree accordingly! Well, we will do the work... Hope you get the idea ;)
In Return for your Contribution we will send you a  TREE-PLANTER E-STICKER for your Social-Media or your Mobile-Phone Background.

We teamed up with the international Organization OneTreePlanted so that we can plant Trees where it's needed the most. Although, we need Trees everywhere! We are also personally involved planting Trees together with our local Partner here in Switzerland.
Always be first to get some awesome Insights from behind the Scenes over our Social-Media Channels.

"What if all Heroes, the Moment they were called to Action, would've decided to wait?"

 

 

 

 

THE MISSION

BE THE CHANGE YOU WISH TO SEE
On our mission to create meaningful connectivity, we are highly determined to drive, encourage and protect freedom of the Arts. We, a small Team of Artists and creative People, are dedicated to contribute great Solutions toward great Advancement and thus an even better Future. Welcome aboard and thank you for joining.
FROM ARTISTS - FOR ARTISTS... 

...FOR YOU TO BE FIRST
Our Focus goes 100% towards improving the Platform. Together with our NewYork (USA) based development Partner, we have been working a total of 7'170 Hours and counting. Since our Start (July 2019) none of us at Team-beetree has been receiving any Salary for their work. Countless Hours for Development & Logo-Design have been covered out of our own Pockets. We are working hard to make it up to your Expectations and we are excited for everything that the Future may bring.

 

​"We believe that everyone deserves the chance to wake up everyday with the opportunity to reach for their potential."
- Sam (Founder @ beetree)

 

 

 

 

MEET THE CREATORS

We are a Switzerland based Bunch of Artists with strict Work-Ethics and the Precision of a Swiss-Watch. To us, this is more than a Project and we will make it succeed no matter what. We are more than happy to walk this Way together with you. Visit us on our Social-Media Channels to get to see our Faces a little bit more often. Please excuse any Typo (German is our native Language).


 

"BECAUSE WE DESERVE A PLATFORM THAT WORKS ACCORDING TO OUR NEEDS!"

- Florence (Founder @ beetree)
 

Do you have any Questions or a Feedback?
Feel free to leave a Comment below, find us on Instagram or Email us 
(we will get back to you within 24 hours)
